speech: Good afternoon and welcome. My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing and we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2% goal. Over the past year we've taken forceful actions to tighten the stance of monetary policy. We've covered a lot of ground and the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt. Even so we have more work to do. Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve and serves as the bedrock of our economy. Without price stability the economy does not work for anyone. In particular, without price stability we will not achieve a sustained period of labor market conditions that benefit all. Today the FOMC raised our policy interest rate by 25 basis points. We continue to anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2% over time. In addition we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet. Storing price stability will likely require maintaining a restrictive stance for some time. I will have more to say about today's monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments. The U.S. economy slowed significantly last year with real GDP rising at a below trend pace of 1%. Recent indicators point to modest growth of spending and production this quarter. Under-spending appears to be expanding at a subdued pace in part reflecting tighter financial conditions over the past year. Activity in the housing sector continues to weaken largely reflecting higher mortgage rates. Higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business fixed investment. Despite the slowdown in growth the labor market remains extremely tight with the unemployment rate at a 50-year low. Job vacancies still very high and wage growth elevated. Job gains have been robust with employment rising by an average of 247,000 jobs per month over the last three months. Although the pace of job gains has slowed over the course of the past year and nominal wage growth has shown some signs of easing the labor market continues to be out of balance. Their demand substantially exceeds the supply of available workers and the labor force participation rate has changed little from a year ago. Inflation remains well above our longer run goal of 2%. Over the 12 months ending in December total PCE prices rose 5.0%. Excluding the volatile food and energy categories core PCE prices rose 4.4%. The inflation data received over the past three months show a welcome reduction in the monthly pace of increases. And while recent developments are encouraging we will need substantially more evidence to be confident that inflation is on a sustained downward path. Despite elevated inflation, longer term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored. As reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets. But that's not grounds for complacency. Although inflation has moderated recently, it remains too high. The longer the current bout of high inflation continues, the greater the chance that expectations of higher inflation will become entrenched. The Fed's monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people. My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials, like food, housing and transportation. We are highly attentive to the risks that inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to a returning inflation to our 2% objective. At today's meeting, the committee raised the target range for the federal front's rate by 25 basis points, bringing the target range to 4.5 to 4.3 quarters percent. And we are continuing the process of significantly reducing the size of our balance sheet. With today's action, we have raised interest rates by 4.5 percentage points over the past year. We continue to anticipate that ongoing increases in the target range for the federal front's rate will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that
extracted_statement_text_8:
Inflation has eased
 somewhat but remains elevated..The Committee anticipates that
 ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary
 policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time..In determining the
 extent of future increases in the target range, the Committee will take into account the
 cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic
 activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..Voting for the monetary policy action were Jerome H. Powell, Chair; John C. Williams,
 Vice Chair; Michael S. Barr; Michelle W. Bowman; Lael Brainard; Lisa D. Cook; Austan D.
 Goolsbee; Patrick Harker; Philip N. Jefferson; Neel Kashkari; Lorie K. Logan; and Christopher
 J. Waller..For release at 2:00 p.m. EST February 1, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on February 1, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 4.65 percent, effective February 2, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to authorize and
 direct the Open Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed
 otherwise, to execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with
 the following domestic policy directive:
 "Effective February 2, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 4-1/2 to 4-3/4 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 4.75 percent, effective February 2, 2023.
extracted_news_25:
Recent readings have indicated that inflation is easing, with the Fed also looking at data that will determine the resilience of the labor market and the pace of wage growth..Advertisement
 Inflation has slowed and the stock market has looked resilient for several months, with many economists crediting the Fed's recent actions as several key economic indicators show inflation easing after peaking last October..For now, inflation remains well above the Fed's 2% target rate but has shown some signs of weakening in recent months, with government data showing a year-over-year drop in inflation in December, which was the slowest rate of increase in more than a year..Financial experts said the latest economic data might lead the Fed to acknowledge that inflation was finally slowing and the economy is showing signs of stabilizing, but Powell was also known to be predictably measured in his words to head off volatility on Wall Street..COMMENTS:
 MICHELE RANERI, VICE PRESIDENT AND HEAD OF U.S. RESEARCH AND CONSULTING, TRANSUNION, CHICAGO
 "This second consecutive lower hike serves as evidence that the Federal Reserve is signaling that significant progress has been made in tamping down inflation and that we have reached a point where rate hikes can be further scaled back..ELLEN HAZEN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, F.L.PUTNAM INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, WELLESLEY, MASSACHUSETTS
 "The key thing the Fed is focused on is wages and we are seeing wage inflation continue to ameliorate if you look at both average hourly earnings and the employment cost index which just came out, wages are beginning to soften, but they are not softening enough to get inflation down to that 2% target..How close are we now with ending the rate hike cycle, when it’s clear employment costs are slowing?".Inflation rates have ebbed somewhat while consumer spending and hiring have slowed and wage increases have moderated — the central bank’s prescribed interest rate hikes, meant to cool the economy and stall price increases, seem to be working..Policy-makers hope to avoid that sort of outcome this time, and economic data since their last policy meeting in December generally has moved in the right direction: Inflation is slowing under the impact of higher interest rates and tighter financial conditions, while the economy continues to grow and create jobs..“While we expect the Fed to downshift the pace of tightening to 25bp increments … we also anticipate a hawkish resolve … policy-makers are encouraged by recent developments, but appear to remain united in the need to ‘keep at it’ with respect to reducing inflation pressures.”
 The Fed’s meeting this week, its first of 2023, will not include new economic forecasts from policy-makers, the most explicit way for them to signal where rates may be headed this year..Since the last Fed meeting in December, two economic trends have made the case for slowing rate hikes: Recent data on wage growth and inflation have been encouraging and economic growth signals have become concerning..That might sound like bad news, but it means that the Fed’s mission to cool the economy and stall price increases is working..Fed officials have said that while they believe they’re on the correct path, they still think there’s a long way to go until they reach their 2% inflation target..“Passing peak inflation is welcome and policymakers appear to have increased confidence that inflation is on a path lower, but the Fed is not yet convinced that inflationary pressures will dissipate quickly,” wrote Bank of America economists in a recent note..The Fed wants to cool hiring and wage increases, which can drive up inflationary pressures..That is close to being consistent with at-target inflation if repeated next quarter.”
 The ECI reading came as another report showed a slowdown in the US housing market as well as a dip in consumer confidence, suggesting the Fed’s tightening campaign is beginning to kick in..ADVERTISEMENT
 Some economists think the Fed doesn’t need to push rates much higher — and that doing so would heighten the risk of a deep recession..Since prices began soaring last year, the Fed has opted to swing, aggressively raising interest rates despite the fact that there’s nothing close to a guarantee that doing so would be best for the economy..The Fed is hoping its interest rate hikes will create more unemployment, which would further ease inflation by reducing people’s spending..The Federal Reserve increased its policy rate to a 4.5% to 4.75% range, which followed six larger rate hikes in a row as the Fed continued its work to tame the worst stretch of inflation in 40 years..And the Fed signaled that even though inflation is easing, it remains high enough to require further rate hikes..“We can now say I think for the first time,” he said, “that the disinflationary process has started.”
 Yet he also stressed that it was too soon to declare victory over the worst inflation bout in four decades: “We will need substantially more evidence to be confident that inflation is on a long, sustained downward path.”
 The Fed’s rate increase Wednesday, though smaller than its half-point hike in December and the four three-quarter-point hikes before that, will likely further raise the costs of many consumer and business loans and the risk of a recession..“I still think there is a path to getting inflation down to 2%,” the Fed’s target level, “without a significant economic decline or significant increase in unemployment,” he said..The U.S. inflation slowdown suggests that the Fed’s rate hikes have started to achieve their goal..More rate hikes are coming: "Powell might acknowledge that the economy is slowing down and inflation is easing, but he's also going to signal the Fed's job is not over."

 MICHELE RANERI, VICE PRESIDENT AND HEAD OF U.S. RESEARCH AND CONSULTING, TRANSUNION, CHICAGO
 "This second consecutive lower hike serves as evidence that the Federal Reserve is signaling that significant progress has been made in tamping down inflation and that we have reached a point where rate hikes can be further scaled back..ELLEN HAZEN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, F.L.PUTNAM INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, WELLESLEY, MASSACHUSETTS
 "The key thing the Fed is focused on is wages and we are seeing wage inflation continue to ameliorate if you look at both average hourly earnings and the employment cost index which just came out, wages are beginning to soften, but they are not softening enough to get inflation down to that 2% target..How close are we now with ending the rate hike cycle, when it’s clear employment costs are slowing?".The Fed is widely seen as raising its target interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point in its first policy meeting of the year, after the rapid increases in 2022 to tame decades-high inflation..The latest figures put additional pressure on the Federal Reserve, which has been trying to slow the labor market with interest-rate hikes..The Fed is targeting the hikes to bring down inflation that, despite recent signs of slowing, is still running near its highest level since the early 1980s..Inflation rates have ebbed somewhat while consumer spending and hiring have slowed and wage increases have moderated — the central bank’s prescribed interest rate hikes, meant to cool the economy and stall price increases, seem to be working..“The persistent lack of inventory, exacerbated by this ‘rate lock,’ is the main reason why we should expect prices to be stable or even rise in the year ahead.”
 
 
 Michael Burry tweeted out a piece of investing advice consisting of just one word, a day before the Federal Reserve's market-moving interest rate decision..Policy-makers hope to avoid that sort of outcome this time, and economic data since their last policy meeting in December generally has moved in the right direction: Inflation is slowing under the impact of higher interest rates and tighter financial conditions, while the economy continues to grow and create jobs..“While we expect the Fed to downshift the pace of tightening to 25bp increments … we also anticipate a hawkish resolve … policy-makers are encouraged by recent developments, but appear to remain united in the need to ‘keep at it’ with respect to reducing inflation pressures.”
 The Fed’s meeting this week, its first of 2023, will not include new economic forecasts from policy-makers, the most explicit way for them to signal where rates may be headed this year..Since the last Fed meeting in December, two economic trends have made the case for slowing rate hikes: Recent data on wage growth and inflation have been encouraging and economic growth signals have become concerning..That might sound like bad news, but it means that the Fed’s mission to cool the economy and stall price increases is working..In December, Powell outlined how he hopes to win his ongoing fight against inflation: Limit economic growth and rebalance the labor market, which he said would allow inflation to return to a growth rate of about 2%..Fed officials have said that while they believe they’re on the correct path, they still think there’s a long way to go until they reach their 2% inflation target..“Passing peak inflation is welcome and policymakers appear to have increased confidence that inflation is on a path lower, but the Fed is not yet convinced that inflationary pressures will dissipate quickly,” wrote Bank of America economists in a recent note..The Fed wants to cool hiring and wage increases, which can drive up inflationary pressures..That is close to being consistent with at-target inflation if repeated next quarter.”
 The ECI reading came as another report showed a slowdown in the US housing market as well as a dip in consumer confidence, suggesting the Fed’s tightening campaign is beginning to kick in..ADVERTISEMENT
 Some economists think the Fed doesn’t need to push rates much higher — and that doing so would heighten the risk of a deep recession..Since prices began soaring last year, the Fed has opted to swing, aggressively raising interest rates despite the fact that there’s nothing close to a guarantee that doing so would be best for the economy..The Fed is hoping its interest rate hikes will create more unemployment, which would further ease inflation by reducing people’s spending..But by ignoring its goal of achieving full employment, the Fed is making lower-wage workers carry the burden of taming inflation by putting them out of work or erasing the significant wage gains they’ve made in the past decade, some of which had actually kept up with inflation before the Fed’s intervention..The Federal Reserve increased its policy rate to a 4.5% to 4.75% range, which followed six larger rate hikes in a row as the Fed continued its work to tame the worst stretch of inflation in 40 years..And the Fed signaled that even though inflation is easing, it remains high enough to require further rate hikes..“We can now say I think for the first time,” he said, “that the disinflationary process has started.”
 Yet he also stressed that it was too soon to declare victory over the worst inflation bout in four decades: “We will need substantially more evidence to be confident that inflation is on a long, sustained downward path.”
 The Fed’s rate increase Wednesday, though smaller than its half-point hike in December and the four three-quarter-point hikes before that, will likely further raise the costs of many consumer and business loans and the risk of a recession..In a statement, Fed officials repeated language they’ve used before, that “ongoing increases in the (interest rate) target range will be appropriate.” That is widely interpreted to mean they will raise their benchmark rate again when they next meet in March and perhaps in May as well..His speech hammered home the Fed’s intent to keep raising rates — even if it caused “pain” in the form of slower growth and higher unemployment..“I still think there is a path to getting inflation down to 2%,” the Fed’s target level, “without a significant economic decline or significant increase in unemployment,” he said..The U.S. inflation slowdown suggests that the Fed’s rate hikes have started to achieve their goal..The Fed’s hike was announced a day after the government said pay and benefits for America’s workers grew more slowly in the final three months of 2022, the third straight slowdown..If all goes as planned, this will mark the eighth consecutive rate hike since March last year, which falls in line with what the Fed warned in December:
 "The Committee anticipates that ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.".More rate hikes are coming: "Powell might acknowledge that the economy is slowing down and inflation is easing, but he's also going to signal the Fed's job is not over."
similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: price stability, FOMC, balance sheet reduction, labor market conditions, elevated wage growth, nominal wage growth, inflation expectations, purchasing power
2. Second Text: economic outlook, Committee goals, reserve balances, open market operations, primary credit rate, cumulative tightening, risks to attainment

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's commitment to controlling inflation and achieving a target rate of 2%.
2. Both mention the robust job gains and low unemployment rates, indicating a tight labor market.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes the ongoing challenges of high inflation and the hardship it causes, while the second text focuses more on the technical aspects of policy implementation and decision-making.
2. The first text elaborates on the impacts of monetary policy on various economic factors, while the second text is more concise and procedural.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a more comprehensive analysis of recent economic indicators and specific data on inflation and employment, while the second text summarizes these elements without as much detail.
2. The first text includes discussions about the potential effects of entrenched inflation expectations, whereas the second text briefly mentions "risks" without elaborating.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "purchasing power" and "nominal wage growth," while the second text employs terminology such as "open market operations" and "cumulative tightening."
2. The first text focuses on "monetary policy actions" and their broader economic implications, while the second text emphasizes "Committee decisions" and operational details regarding interest rates.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text exhibits a slightly more positive emotional bias compared to the second text. Phrases like "we have more work to do" and "the inflation data received over the past three months show a welcome reduction" suggest a sense of optimism regarding future progress despite current challenges. In contrast, the second text, while factual, contains phrases such as "inflation has eased somewhat but remains elevated," which implies a more neutral stance with less optimism about the situation. The first text emphasizes commitment and responsiveness with statements like "we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down," whereas the second text is more matter-of-fact, outlining decisions without the explicit emotional engagement seen in the first.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text expresses higher levels of certainty than the second text. It states, "we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down," indicating a firm belief and confidence in the Federal Reserve's goals and actions. There are additional emphatic statements, such as "the labor market remains extremely tight" and "we will need substantially more evidence to be confident," which assert a robust understanding of the economic landscape. Conversely, the second text uses language that presents a more measured certainty, with phrases like "the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy" and "would be prepared to adjust," reflecting a conditional approach that suggests less decisiveness. Overall, the first text conveys a stronger assurance in both assessment and action regarding monetary policy.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: monetary policy, FOMC, price stability, core PCE prices, inflation expectations, labor market conditions
2. Second Text: soft landing, wage growth, Consumer Price Index, economic pain, disinflationary process, Federal Open Market Committee

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's actions to combat high inflation and mention raising interest rates.
2. Each text acknowledges that inflation remains above the desired 2% target but shows signs of easing.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes the responsibility of the Fed for price stability and its impact on the economy, focusing on monetary policy actions and their anticipated outcomes.
2. The second text has a more market-focused perspective, discussing how the Fed's actions are perceived by investors and economists, as well as the potential for slower interest rate hikes.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a detailed analysis of the current economic situation, mentioning specific metrics such as job growth and GDP trends.
2. The second text centers on the immediate implications of recent economic data and Fed meetings, with quotes from Fed officials and economists reflecting different perceptions of the same data.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms such as "restrictive stance" and "balance sheet reduction," focusing on technical aspects of monetary policy.
2. The second text employs terms like "soft landing" and "economic pain," which indicate broader economic outcomes and sentiments related to the Fed's decisions.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text presents a more optimistic tone in its acknowledgment of economic challenges and actions to address them. Phrases like "we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down" and "we continue to anticipate that ongoing increases will be appropriate" suggest an active and hopeful approach toward managing inflation and promoting economic stability. In contrast, the second text has a more cautious perspective, exemplified by the phrase "the Fed is widely seen as raising its target interest rate," which implies a sense of reactiveness rather than proactive commitment. Additionally, the second text mentions "the persistent lack of inventory" and "heightened risk of a deep recession," which carries a slightly negative undertone compared to the first text's assurances of progress and commitment.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text reflects a high level of certainty, particularly in phrases such as "the full effects of our rapid tightening so far are yet to be felt" and "price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve." These phrases convey confidence in the actions being taken and their expected outcomes. On the other hand, the second text expresses a more moderate level of certainty. For example, the section "the Fed is not yet convinced that inflationary pressures will dissipate quickly" indicates a level of doubt and indicates pending evaluation rather than assurance. Additionally, the phrase "we will need substantially more evidence to be confident that inflation is on a long, sustained downward path" highlights a cautious approach, contrasting with the first text's more assured and assertive stance.

speech: to 2% over time. We are seeing the effects of our policy actions on demand in the most intracensitive sectors of the economy, particularly housing. People take time, however, for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation. In light of the cumulative tightening of monetary policy and the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, the committee decided to raise interest rates by 25 basis points today, continuing the step down from last year's rapid pace of increases. Shifting to a slower pace will better allow the committee to assess the economy's progress toward our goals, as we determine the extent of future increases that we required to attain a sufficiently restrictive stance. We will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting, taking into account the totality of incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation. We have been taking forceful steps to moderate demand so that it comes into better alignment with supply. Our overarching focus is using our tools to bring inflation back down to our 2% goal and to keep longer term inflation expectations well anchored. Reducing inflation is likely to require a period of below trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions. Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run. The historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy. We will stay the course until the job is done. To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families and businesses across the country, everything we do is in service to our public mission. We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum employment and price stability goals. Thank you. I look forward to your questions. Chris. Good game. Chris Rugeber to associate at press. Thank you for doing this. As you know, financial conditions have loosened since the fall with bond yields falling, which is also brought down mortgage rates in the stock market posted a solid game in January. Does that make your job of combating inflation harder and could you see lifting rates higher than you otherwise would to offset the increase in or to offset the easing of financial conditions? It is important that overall financial conditions continue to reflect the policy or strength that we are putting in place in order to bring inflation down to 2%. And of course financial conditions have tightened very significantly over the past year. I would say that our focus is not on short-term moves but on sustained changes to broader financial conditions. And it is our judgment that we are not yet at a sufficiently restrictive policy stance, which is why we say that we expect ongoing hikes will be appropriate. Of course many things affect financial conditions, not just our policy. And we will take into account overall financial conditions along with many other factors as we said policy. Rachel. Hi, Chair Powell. Thank you for taking our questions. Rachel Siegel from the Washington Post. Over the last quarter we have seen a deceleration in prices, in wages and a fall in consumer spending. All while the unemployment rate has been able to stay at a historic low. Does this at all change your view of how much the unemployment rate would need to go up if at all to see inflation come down to the levels you are looking for? So I would say it is a good thing that the disinflation that we have seen so far has not come at the expense of a weaker labor market. But I would also say that that disinflationary process that you now see underway is really at an early stage. What you see is really in the good sector, you see inflation now coming down because supply chains have been fixed, demand is shifting back to services and shortages or have been abated. So you see that in the other, in the housing services sector, we expect inflation to continue moving up for a while but then to come down assuming that new leases continue to be lower. So in those two sectors you have got a good story. The issue is that we have a large sector called non-housing, core non-housing services where we don't see disinflation yet. But I would say that so far what we see is progress but without any weakening in labor market conditions. Has your expectation for where the unemployment rate might go change since December? We are going to write down new forecasts at the March meeting and we will see at that time. I will stick to that.

 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on February 1, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 4.65 percent, effective February 2, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to authorize and
 direct the Open Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed
 otherwise, to execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with
 the following domestic policy directive:
 "Effective February 2, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 4-1/2 to 4-3/4 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 4.75 percent, effective February 2, 2023.

The Fed is widely seen as raising its target interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point in its first policy meeting of the year, after rapid increases in 2022 to tame decades-high inflation..Recent readings have indicated that inflation is easing, with the Fed also looking at data that will determine the resilience of the labor market and the pace of wage growth..For now, inflation remains well above the Fed's 2% target rate but has shown some signs of weakening in recent months, with government data showing a year-over-year drop in inflation in December, which was the slowest rate of increase in more than a year..Financial experts said the latest economic data might lead the Fed to acknowledge that inflation was finally slowing and the economy is showing signs of stabilizing, but Powell was also known to be predictably measured in his words to head off volatility on Wall Street..The expected increase is the eighth in a series begun in March 2022 aimed at curbing high inflation.…
 Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will speak with the press following the conclusion of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which is expected to result in a quarter-point rate increase, the smallest hike in almost a year..ELLEN HAZEN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, F.L.PUTNAM INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, WELLESLEY, MASSACHUSETTS
 "The key thing the Fed is focused on is wages and we are seeing wage inflation continue to ameliorate if you look at both average hourly earnings and the employment cost index which just came out, wages are beginning to soften, but they are not softening enough to get inflation down to that 2% target..The Fed is widely seen as raising its target interest rate by a quarter of a percentage point in its first policy meeting of the year, after the rapid increases in 2022 to tame decades-high inflation..The Fed is targeting the hikes to bring down inflation that, despite recent signs of slowing, is still running near its highest level since the early 1980s..So will Fed Chair Jerome Powell dampen expectations and reiterate that the fight against inflation still has a way to go, or will the Fed show signs that they’re ready to ease up on rate hikes?.Inflation rates have ebbed somewhat while consumer spending and hiring have slowed and wage increases have moderated — the central bank’s prescribed interest rate hikes, meant to cool the economy and stall price increases, seem to be working..Traditionally the Fed raises interest rates by quarter percentage point increments, but persistently high inflation pushed it to act more aggressively..But now they're wondering when the Fed will stop as it walks a shaky tightrope between lowering inflation to its 2% target and pushing the economy into recession..Policy-makers hope to avoid that sort of outcome this time, and economic data since their last policy meeting in December generally has moved in the right direction: Inflation is slowing under the impact of higher interest rates and tighter financial conditions, while the economy continues to grow and create jobs..Some analysts do expect the Fed to remove from its policy statement the current, open-ended promise of “ongoing increases” in interest rates, a phrase used since the central bank began its tightening cycle in March..“While we expect the Fed to downshift the pace of tightening to 25bp increments … we also anticipate a hawkish resolve … policy-makers are encouraged by recent developments, but appear to remain united in the need to ‘keep at it’ with respect to reducing inflation pressures.”
 The Fed’s meeting this week, its first of 2023, will not include new economic forecasts from policy-makers, the most explicit way for them to signal where rates may be headed this year..As of December, policy-makers’ median forecast was for the Fed’s target interest rate to peak in a range between 5.00 per cent and 5.25 per cent, an outlook that would imply a pause in the policy tightening after two more quarter-percentage-point increases..Will Fed Chair Jerome Powell dampen expectations and reiterate that the fight against inflation still has “a ways to go,” or will Fed officials signal that they’re ready to ease up on rate hikes?.Since the last Fed meeting in December, two economic trends have made the case for slowing rate hikes: Recent data on wage growth and inflation have been encouraging and economic growth signals have become concerning..Fed officials have said that while they believe they’re on the correct path, they still think there’s a long way to go until they reach their 2% inflation target..At that point, they’re expected to hold rates steady while they assess the impact on inflation..The Fed wants to cool hiring and wage increases, which can drive up inflationary pressures..Yet Fed officials have said they would need to see further evidence that inflation was declining closer to its 2% target before they would consider suspending their rate hikes..Some economists think the Fed doesn't need to push rates much higher — and that doing so would heighten the risk of a deep recession..Since March, the statement has said that “ongoing increases in the (interest rate) target range will be appropriate.” Some economists expect officials to slightly alter that part of the statement to make it a less specific commitment and give the Fed more flexibility..ADVERTISEMENT
 Some economists think the Fed doesn’t need to push rates much higher — and that doing so would heighten the risk of a deep recession..Since prices began soaring last year, the Fed has opted to swing, aggressively raising interest rates despite the fact that there’s nothing close to a guarantee that doing so would be best for the economy..The Fed is hoping its interest rate hikes will create more unemployment, which would further ease inflation by reducing people’s spending..The Federal Reserve increased its policy rate to a 4.5% to 4.75% range, which followed six larger rate hikes in a row as the Fed continued its work to tame the worst stretch of inflation in 40 years..And the Fed signaled that even though inflation is easing, it remains high enough to require further rate hikes..“We can now say I think for the first time,” he said, “that the disinflationary process has started.”
 Yet he also stressed that it was too soon to declare victory over the worst inflation bout in four decades: “We will need substantially more evidence to be confident that inflation is on a long, sustained downward path.”
 The Fed’s rate increase Wednesday, though smaller than its half-point hike in December and the four three-quarter-point hikes before that, will likely further raise the costs of many consumer and business loans and the risk of a recession..In a statement, Fed officials repeated language they’ve used before, that “ongoing increases in the (interest rate) target range will be appropriate.” That is widely interpreted to mean they will raise their benchmark rate again when they next meet in March and perhaps in May as well..The U.S. inflation slowdown suggests that the Fed’s rate hikes have started to achieve their goal..The Fed’s hike was announced a day after the government said pay and benefits for America’s workers grew more slowly in the final three months of 2022, the third straight slowdown..If all goes as planned, this will mark the eighth consecutive rate hike since March last year, which falls in line with what the Fed warned in December:
 "The Committee anticipates that ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time.".More rate hikes are coming: "Powell might acknowledge that the economy is slowing down and inflation is easing, but he's also going to signal the Fed's job is not over."

Inflation has eased
 somewhat but remains elevated..The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of
 2 percent over the longer run..In support of these goals, the Committee decided to raise the
 target range for the federal funds rate to 4-1/2 to 4-3/4 percent..The Committee anticipates that
 ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary
 policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time..In determining the
 extent of future increases in the target range, the Committee will take into account the
 cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic
 activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments..The Committee is strongly
 committed to returning inflation to its 2 percent objective..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..The Committee
 would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that
 (more)

 could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals..The Committee’s assessments will take
 into account a wide range of information, including readings on labor market conditions,
 inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and financial and international developments..Voting for the monetary policy action were Jerome H. Powell, Chair; John C. Williams,
 Vice Chair; Michael S. Barr; Michelle W. Bowman; Lael Brainard; Lisa D. Cook; Austan D.
 Goolsbee; Patrick Harker; Philip N. Jefferson; Neel Kashkari; Lorie K. Logan; and Christopher
 J. Waller..For release at 2:00 p.m. EST February 1, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on February 1, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 4.65 percent, effective February 2, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to authorize and
 direct the Open Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed
 otherwise, to execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with
 the following domestic policy directive:
 "Effective February 2, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 4-1/2 to 4-3/4 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 4.75 percent, effective February 2, 2023..In taking this action, the Board approved requests
 to establish that rate submitted by the Boards of Directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of
 Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Richmond, Atlanta, Chicago, Kansas City, Dallas, and
 San Francisco..(more)

 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools

similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: "totality of incoming data", "historical record", "disinflation", "softening of labor market conditions", "monetary restraint"
2. Second Text: "target range for the federal funds rate", "cumulative tightening of monetary policy", "sufficiently restrictive", "Board of Governors", "interest rate paid on reserve balances"

Similarities:

1. Both texts emphasize the goal of achieving a 2% inflation rate and maximum employment.
2. They both discuss the need for future increases in interest rates to maintain a restrictive monetary policy stance.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the effects of monetary policy on various sectors of the economy, emphasizing consumer impacts and employment concerns, while the second text is more procedural and highlights the specific details of the monetary policy decisions.
2. The first text discusses the challenges and current progress of disinflation in a conversational tone, whereas the second text has a more formal tone that addresses policy assessment and implementation.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a broader context with discussions about community impacts and the historical caution against loosening policy, while the second text focuses on the specific actions and decisions of the Federal Open Market Committee.
2. The second text includes the voting members of the Committee and specific operational directives, while the first text does not mention committee members or detailed procedural steps.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms and phrases like "forceful steps", "moderate demand", and "maximum employment", which focus on the dynamic aspects of policy effects, while the second text uses more formal terminology such as "federal funds rate" and "reserve balances", indicating the mechanics of monetary policy.
2. The first text speaks of "disinflation" in a qualitative sense, while the second text refers to "sufficiently restrictive" as a quantitative assessment of policy effect.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text conveys a subtly more optimistic sentiment regarding the outlook for inflation and economic activity. Phrases such as "we have been taking forceful steps to moderate demand" and "we will stay the course until the job is done" reflect a proactive and determined approach that emphasizes confidence in achieving monetary policy goals. This contrasts with the second text, which utilizes language like "inflation has eased somewhat but remains elevated," which indicates a more cautious tone and acknowledgment of ongoing challenges. The overall focus in the first text on "understanding that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses" underscores a commitment to positive long-term impacts, reinforcing a slightly more positive emotional bias.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: lower certainty
Explanation: The first text presents a lower level of certainty compared to the second text, as seen in phrases like "we will continue to make our decisions meeting by meeting" and "I would say that so far what we see is progress." This language reflects a degree of caution and a recognition of variable economic conditions, suggesting that outcomes are not guaranteed. In contrast, the second text articulates a more confident assertion that "the Committee is strongly committed to returning inflation to its 2 percent objective," which indicates higher certainty in its objectives and actions. The specificity in the commitments and plans in the second text enhances its certain tone when compared to the more tentative expressions in the first text.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: inflation expectations anchored, disinflationary process, labor market conditions, monetary restraint, cumulative tightening
2. Second Text: decades-high inflation, wage growth, economic growth signals, ongoing increases, tightrope between lowering inflation

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's interest rate hike as a response to inflation and economic conditions.
2. Both texts emphasize the importance of inflation rates in determining monetary policy and the significance of the labor market.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the long-term goals of bringing inflation to the target rate and the careful approach of monetary policy, while the second text emphasizes current high inflation and the pressure for immediate action.
2. The first text conveys a more cautious and methodical tone regarding future rate hikes, whereas the second text showcases more speculation and uncertainty about the Fed's decision-making process.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides detailed insights into the reasoning behind the Fed's actions and their implications for the economy, focusing more on internal deliberation and policy-making.
2. The second text prominently features external viewpoints and opinions from financial experts and insiders regarding future policy actions.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "sufficiently restrictive stance" and "monetary restraint," which emphasize the Fed's ongoing commitment to controlling inflation.
2. The second text includes terms like "decades-high inflation" and "tightrope," which highlight the urgency and precariousness of the current economic situation.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text conveys a slightly more positive emotional bias through phrases that indicate proactive measures and acknowledgment of effects from policy actions, such as "We have been taking forceful steps to moderate demand" and "Shifting to a slower pace will better allow the committee to assess the economy's progress." These phrases suggest optimism about the policies being effective and the potential for achieving goals like inflation reduction. In contrast, the second text takes a more cautious tone, hinting at lingering challenges with remarks like "the economy is showing signs of stabilizing" and the acknowledgment of "a shaky tightrope between lowering inflation" and potential economic recession. This indicates a more careful and less optimistic view of the economic situation.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text displays a higher level of certainty with assertive phrases like "we will stay the course until the job is done" and "the historical record cautions strongly against prematurely loosening policy," indicating strong confidence in the steps being taken by the committee. In contrast, the second text shows moderate certainty with phrases such as "some economists think the Fed doesn't need to push rates much higher" and "there’s a long way to go until they reach their 2% inflation target," which suggest a level of uncertainty and speculation about future actions. This difference in language demonstrates that the first text expresses more definitive assurance regarding policy effectiveness.

speech: that it is gratifying to see the disinflationary process now getting underway and we continue to get strong labor market data. So we'll update those forecasts in March. Neil. Hi Chair Powell, Neil or one of the axios. You and some of your colleagues have emphasized the possibility that job openings could come down and that would let some of the air out of the labor market without major job losses. We saw the opposite in the December Jolt's morning job openings actually rising. That also coincided with slowdown wage inflation. Do you believe that openings are important indicator to be studying to understand where the labor market is and where wage inflation might be heading? So you're right about the data of course. We did see, we've seen our jar early earnings and now the employment cost index abating a little bit still off of their highs of six months ago and more but still at levels that are fairly elevated. The job openings number in Jolt's has been quite volatile recently and I did see that it moved up back up this morning. I do think that it's probably an important indicator. The ratio I guess is back up to 1.9 job openings to unemployed people, people who are looking for work. So it's an indicator, nonetheless you're right. We do see wages moving down. If you look across the rest of the labor market you still see very high payroll job creation and quits are still at an elevated level. So by many, many indicators the job market is still very strong. Colby and then how is it? Thank you. Colby Smith with the Financial Times. Given the economic data since the December meeting is the trajectory for the Fed funds rate in the most recent SEP still the best guide post for the policy path forward or does ongoing now mean more than two rate rises now. So you're right at the December meeting we all wrote down our best estimates of what we thought the ultimate level would be and that's obviously back in December and the median for that was between five and five and a quarter percent. At the March meeting we're going to update those assessments. We did not update them today. We did, however, continue to say that we believe on going rate hikes will be appropriate to attain a sufficiently restrictive stance of policy to bring inflation back down to two percent. We think we've covered a lot of ground and financial additions of certainly tightened. I would say we still think there's work to do there. We haven't made a decision on exactly where that will be. I think we're going to be looking carefully at the incoming data between now and the March meeting and then the May meeting. I don't feel a lot of certainty about where that will be. It could certainly be higher than we're writing down right now. If we come to the view that we need to write down to move rates up beyond what we said in December we would certainly do that. At the same time if the data come in in the other direction then we'll make data dependent decisions at coming meetings of course. Just as a quick follow up, how are you viewing the kind of balance of risk between those two options of the likelihood of maybe falling short of that or going beyond that level? I guess I would say it this way. I continue to think that it's very difficult to manage the risk of doing too little and finding out in six or 12 months that we actually were close but didn't get the job done. Inflation springs back and we have to go back in. And now you really do worry about expectations getting unanchored and that kind of thing. This is a very difficult risk to manage. Whereas we have no incentive in the desire to over tighten. But if we feel like we've gone too far we can certainly, because the concern and inflation is coming down faster than we expect then we have tools that would work on that. So I do think that in this situation where we have still the highest inflation in 40 years the job is not fully done. As I mentioned, I started to mention earlier, we have a sector that is 56% of the core inflation index where we don't see disinflation yet. So we don't see it. It's not happening yet. Inflation in the core services X housing is still running at 4% on a 6 and 12 month basis. So there's nothing happening there. In the other two sectors representing less than 50%, you actually I think now have a story that is credible that's coming together. Although you don't actually see disinflation yet in housing services, but it's in the pipeline. So for the third sector we don't see anything here. So I think it would be premature. We very premature to declare victory or to the end of the year.

 Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell will speak with the press following the conclusion of the Federal Open Market Committee meeting, which is expected to result in a quarter-point rate increase, the smallest hike in almost a year..“With Fed officials hoping for signs of slowing hiring to support wage growth deceleration, every data point matters,'' said Matthew Martin, U.S. economist at Oxford Economics.."It's a good thing for the Fed that inflation pressures are cooling because the labor market isn't cooling at all.".ELLEN HAZEN, CHIEF MARKET STRATEGIST, F.L.PUTNAM INVESTMENT MANAGEMENT, WELLESLEY, MASSACHUSETTS
 "The key thing the Fed is focused on is wages and we are seeing wage inflation continue to ameliorate if you look at both average hourly earnings and the employment cost index which just came out, wages are beginning to soften, but they are not softening enough to get inflation down to that 2% target.."Yesterday's Employment Cost Index was an improvement, and Powell said he needed to see employment costs improve before he stops hiking rates..How close are we now with ending the rate hike cycle, when it’s clear employment costs are slowing?".The key word is “ongoing” — as in, whether the committee still feels that “ongoing increases” in interest rates are necessary given signs in recent data that inflation is cooling..So will Fed Chair Jerome Powell dampen expectations and reiterate that the fight against inflation still has a way to go, or will the Fed show signs that they’re ready to ease up on rate hikes?.Inflation rates have ebbed somewhat while consumer spending and hiring have slowed and wage increases have moderated — the central bank’s prescribed interest rate hikes, meant to cool the economy and stall price increases, seem to be working..Policy-makers hope to avoid that sort of outcome this time, and economic data since their last policy meeting in December generally has moved in the right direction: Inflation is slowing under the impact of higher interest rates and tighter financial conditions, while the economy continues to grow and create jobs..Some analysts do expect the Fed to remove from its policy statement the current, open-ended promise of “ongoing increases” in interest rates, a phrase used since the central bank began its tightening cycle in March..“While we expect the Fed to downshift the pace of tightening to 25bp increments … we also anticipate a hawkish resolve … policy-makers are encouraged by recent developments, but appear to remain united in the need to ‘keep at it’ with respect to reducing inflation pressures.”
 The Fed’s meeting this week, its first of 2023, will not include new economic forecasts from policy-makers, the most explicit way for them to signal where rates may be headed this year..With the careful communication path Powell must walk in mind, here's what to expect when the FOMC's post-meeting statement is released at 2 pm ET:
 Rates
 Over the past few weeks, Fed officials have been explicit in stating that, at the very least, they can start approving smaller moves than the four consecutive 0.75 percentage point increases approved in 2022..Will Fed Chair Jerome Powell dampen expectations and reiterate that the fight against inflation still has “a ways to go,” or will Fed officials signal that they’re ready to ease up on rate hikes?.Since the last Fed meeting in December, two economic trends have made the case for slowing rate hikes: Recent data on wage growth and inflation have been encouraging and economic growth signals have become concerning..At the same time, Chair Jerome Powell said at a news conference that the Fed recognizes that the pace of inflation has cooled — a signal that it could be nearing the end of its rate increases..The Fed’s hike was announced a day after the government said pay and benefits for America’s workers grew more slowly in the final three months of 2022, the third straight slowdown..More rate hikes are coming: "Powell might acknowledge that the economy is slowing down and inflation is easing, but he's also going to signal the Fed's job is not over."."Powell might acknowledge that the economy is slowing down and inflation is easing, but he's also going to signal the Fed's job is not over.".“A downshift in ECI wage growth in Q4 would not immediately stop Fed officials talking about their intention to raise rates further.
extracted_statement_text_10:
For release at 2:00 p.m. EST February 1, 2023
 Recent indicators point to modest growth in spending and production..Job gains have
 been robust in recent months, and the unemployment rate has remained low..Inflation has eased
 somewhat but remains elevated..In determining the
 extent of future increases in the target range, the Committee will take into account the
 cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic
 activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..The Committee’s assessments will take
 into account a wide range of information, including readings on labor market conditions,
 inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and financial and international developments..For release at 2:00 p.m. EST February 1, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on February 1, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 4.65 percent, effective February 2, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to authorize and
 direct the Open Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed
 otherwise, to execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with
 the following domestic policy directive:
 "Effective February 2, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 4-1/2 to 4-3/4 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 4.75 percent, effective February 2, 2023..(more)

 This information will be updated as appropriate to reflect decisions of the Federal Open Market
 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools
 and approach used to implement monetary policy.

 ongoing increases in the target range will be appropriate in order to attain a stance of monetary

 MICHELE RANERI, VICE PRESIDENT AND HEAD OF U.S. RESEARCH AND CONSULTING, TRANSUNION, CHICAGO
