financial stability and monetary policy goals..Emergency borrowing has driven up the overall level of Fed holdings, but the Fed continues to shed bonds and cut the level of reserves in the banking system, which is how the QT process has worked all along, he said..Even with a jump in the balance sheet the Fed is “still credit tightening” and when it comes to the increase in the overall size, “it’s hard for me to imagine that this is remotely inflationary,” Durham said..Matthew Luzzetti, chief U.S. economist at Deutsche Bank Securities, said “a tightening of bank lending conditions could lead to a broader tightening of financial conditions that would meaningfully dent growth prospects and heighten recession probabilities.”
 LESS ROOM TO RUN?.But even with that caveat, the firm saw some potential implications for how the Fed proceeds with its balance sheet drawdown, depending on banks' reserve positions..“If some of the recent surge in emergency lending runs off in the weeks ahead, it may very well be the case that this episode has nudged the banking system closer to the point of effective reserve scarcity rather than farther away.”
 Reporting by Michael S. Derby; Editing by Dan Burns and Andrea Ricci
 Our Standards: The Thomson Reuters Trust Principles..“It’s just not easy for them right now.”
 In a note to clients Monday, economists at Goldman Sachs said that while policymakers at the Fed and in Europe have responded aggressively to shore up the global financial system, “markets appear to be less than fully convinced that efforts to support small and midsize banks will prove sufficient.”
 As a result, they wrote, they “think Fed officials will therefore share our view that stress in the banking system remains the most immediate concern for now” and will hold off on another increase..What’s happening: Fears of a bank run cause lenders to take fewer risks with their capital reserves to ensure they have enough cash to cover any potential withdrawal requests, said analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics..Mohamed El-Erian, chief economic adviser at Allianz, wrote in The Financial Times this week that if the Fed doesn’t increase interest rates, it would “set up more policy flip-flops that fail to deliver a soft landing while amplifying unsettling financial volatility.”
 In an interview with Bloomberg this week, former US Treasury Secretary Larry Summers said the Fed should be wary of falling prey to financial dominance — when the Fed doesn’t tighten monetary policy because of potential risks to the stability of the financial system..What comes next for the banking industry is largely dependent on the Federal Reserve’s policy decision and whether banks remain above water for the time being..So the Fed may decide to take a pause here just to see how things settle down.”
 Economists at Goldman Sachs also expect the Fed to pause, writing in a note to clients this week that “stress in the banking system remains the most immediate concern right now.”
 The Fed is set to announce its policy decision Wednesday at 2 p.m..ET, with Chair Powell’s news conference scheduled for 2:30 p.m.
 
 
 Is the Federal Reserve, charged with supervising the banks for which it is the primary regulator, too chummy or aligned with those banks to do its job?.Amid these failures, a question that took hold during the 2008 financial crisis has resurfaced: Is the Federal Reserve, charged with supervising the banks for which it is the primary regulator, too chummy or aligned with them to do the job?.Yellen said a new emergency lending facility launched by the Fed, along with its existing discount window, are “working as intended to provide liquidity to the banking system.”
 But prior to the closures of Silicon Valley Bank and Signature Bank, analysts had widely predicted that the Fed would unveil a half-point rate hike..But after the sudden collapse of the two banks that sent shockwaves across the global economy, there has been a growing belief among Wall Street analysts that the central bank will pull back, and only raise rates by a quarter-point – in part to try to alleviate concerns that the Fed’s historically aggressive rate hikes over the past year were precisely to blame for this month’s financial turmoil.."The Fed will likely stress that another hike is needed to cool the economy and tame inflation, which remains well above their target, but also highlight the actions taken and tools available to them to help alleviate the stress in the banking system.".At the same time, the Fed warned that the financial upheaval stemming from the collapse of two major banks is “likely to result in tighter credit conditions” and “weigh on economic activity, hiring and inflation.”
 The central bank also signalled that it’s likely nearing the end of its aggressive series of rate hikes..Fed monetary policymakers have had to weigh continuing their aggressive fight on still-high inflation against concerns about the stability of US banks, whose finances have been rocked by those fast-rising interest rates over the past year..Powell has faced sharp criticism for allowing the collapse on his watch as well as reducing oversight of large regional banks with new discretion given to the Fed by a 2018 law that eased some tough regulations put in place after the financial crisis a decade earlier..Despite the federal government's bailout of Silicon Valley Bank depositors, which Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen asserted was done to minimize the risk of financial contagion, investors are clamoring for the Fed to halt monetary tightening..About $300 billion in assets added to Fed balance sheet in the last week pic.twitter.com/a46TLAkFwr — Genevieve Roch-Decter, CFA (@GRDecter) March 16, 2023
 Raising interest rates while expanding its balance sheet may sound a bit like pressing the gas pedal and the brake at the same time.
similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: discount window, enhanced lending facility, balance sheet reduction, reserve shortages, monetary policy stance, liquidity provision, interest rate risk, supervisory changes, unhedged long positions, depositors' savings
2. Second Text: tighter credit conditions, cumulative tightening, monetary policy firming, implications for economic activity, economic and financial developments, interest rate paid on reserve balances, primary credit rate, open market operations, federal funds rate target range, agency mortgage-backed securities

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and its implications for the banking system and the economy.
2. Both texts mention monitoring economic conditions and making adjustments to policies based on incoming information.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the specific mechanisms and tools used by the Fed, such as liquidity provisions and supervisory issues concerning banks, whereas the second text emphasizes broader economic impacts like credit conditions and inflation targets.
2. The first text has a more conversational tone with questions raised by a reporter, while the second text presents a more formal, structured outline of policy decisions.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text includes detailed discussions on the Fed's concerns with banks, interest rate risks, and past supervisory engagement, whereas the second text provides detailed statistics on policy actions taken by the Federal Open Market Committee.
2. The first text addresses specific instances related to depositors and bank failures, while the second text concentrates on the projected outcomes of current monetary policy decisions on economic metrics.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "discount window" and "enhanced lending facility," which focus on liquidity and bank support mechanisms, while the second text refers to terms like "tightening of monetary policy" and "interest rate paid on reserve balances," which focus on broader monetary policy actions.
2. The second text includes operational jargon such as "open market operations" and "federal funds rate target range," that are not present in the first text.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text demonstrates a slightly more positive emotional bias as it expresses confidence in the effectiveness of certain monetary policy tools. Phrases like "we do believe that it's working" and "it's having its intended effect of bolstering confidence into the banking system" suggest an optimistic viewpoint regarding the actions of the Federal Reserve. In contrast, the second text features phrases such as "likely to result in tighter credit conditions" and "weigh on economic activity," which indicate concern and a more cautious tone towards future economic conditions. The overall framing of the first text leans towards assuring stakeholders of current measures, while the second text emphasizes potential risks and challenges.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text showcases a higher level of certainty through definitive statements, such as "we think that our program of allowing our balance sheet to run off predictably and passively is working," indicating a strong belief in the effectiveness of policy measures. In contrast, the second text contains phrases like "the Committee will closely monitor incoming information" and "some additional policy firming may be appropriate," suggesting a more cautious and reactive approach, which conveys lower certainty regarding future economic conditions. Therefore, the first text’s expressions of confidence exhibit a greater level of certainty compared to the more tentative assertions found in the second text.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: financial supports, discount window, balance sheet reduction, large scale purchases, monetary policy stance, temporary lending, confidence in the banking system, supervisory team, runs on non bank financial institutions, interest rate risk, reserve shortages
2. Second Text: rolling bank sector crisis, emergency lending facility, swap lines, financial stability concerns, inflation dragon, banking conference, global financial system, personal consumption expenditures, financial dominance, chummy or aligned

Similarities:

1. Both texts address the balance between monetary policy and financial stability amidst recent banking sector stress.
2. Both discuss the Federal Reserve's actions and implications of interest rate hikes in the context of banking crises and liquidity.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes a technical and procedural overview of the Federal Reserve's operations in response to banking stress, while the second text presents a more narrative-driven account of the ongoing crisis and responses from various officials.
2. The second text highlights the urgency and implications of the banking crisis on market behavior, emphasizing investor sentiment and potential panic, while the first text is more focused on the technicalities of monetary policy.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text delves deeper into the mechanics of the Fed's monetary policy tools and the implications for its balance sheet, while the second text discusses the broader context of investor expectations and market conditions.
2. The second text provides examples of specific recent events (such as the takeover of Credit Suisse) and their effects on market dynamics whereas the first text maintains a more academic viewpoint without detailing specific incidents as extensively.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "quantitative easing," "discount window," and "temporary lending," which are more technical, whereas the second text employs phrases like "bank sector crisis" and "emergency lending facility," which convey urgency.
2. The second text references "inflation dragon" and "financial dominance," which are not found in the first text, indicating a more colloquial tone in articulating economic challenges.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text carries a slightly more positive emotional bias than the second text. Phrases such as "we do believe that it's working" and "it's having its intended effect of bolstering confidence into the banking system" indicate a hopeful outlook regarding the effectiveness of the Fed's interventions. In contrast, the second text presents a more cautious tone, with statements like "investors are expecting the Fed to keep policy on hold" and "the situation is destabilizing." These phrases suggest a level of concern that is less pronounced in the first text, highlighting a clarity of purpose and optimism in the Fed's actions in the first text.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text exhibits a higher level of certainty compared to the second text. The first speaker expresses confidence in the Fed's ability to manage liquidity and maintain the banking system's stability, as seen in phrases like "we think that our program...is working" and "we don't see any evidence that that's changed." This conveys a strong assurance of the Fed's mechanisms. Conversely, the second text is marked by a more speculative tone, featuring phrases like "many investors are expecting" and "the Fed faces a dilemma," which indicate uncertainty regarding future actions and expectations about market responses. This difference in tone contributes to a sense of greater confidence in the first text's assertions compared to the cautiousness of the second.

speech: regulatory, particularly immediate attention. That's, I guess, there were six of them. So. And getting to the seriousness of it, how are you going to ensure that banks comply with these citations take them seriously? How will you enforce them? That is a great question. And is right in the heart of what the review will be doing under Vice Chair of Barr's leadership. So I think that's what you think about. What can we do to make sure that? But again, that's not for me to answer today. Do you have specific thoughts on that? Well, I see if I did, I wouldn't share them, because I really, this review is going on. And I want nothing other than us to find out what happened and why, figure out what we can do to do better, and then implement those changes. That's all I want. It's for me to be giving you my half-form to or partially informed thoughts. It just isn't appropriate. There's a real serious review going on with people from all of the Federal Reserve system who are not connected to this work, not connected to this bank. And under, again, Vice Chair of Barr's leadership, and I'm confident that it will produce a satisfactory result. OK. We'll go to Jennifer for the last question. Thank you, Chair Powell, Jennifer Sean Berger with Yahoo Finance. Carrie, how do you view financial conditions right now? If credit becomes expensive enough, choking off growth, as you said you're watching for, would that situation warrant a rate cut? What situation would warrant a rate cut? And have the bank failures prompted any discussion around changing the implementation of the balance sheet runoff? Thank you. So we haven't really talked about changing the balance sheet implementation. That's not something we've discussed yet. As I mentioned, we're always willing to change that if we conclude that it's appropriate, but we're really not seeing any signs there. Sorry. Then the question before that was just give me a... Carrie, how you view financial conditions now, and if credit were to tighten enough, if that would prompt a rate cut. So financial conditions seem to have tightened, and probably by more than the traditional indexes say, because the traditional indexes are focused a lot on rates and equities, and they don't necessarily capture lending conditions. So we think that, though. So there are other measures, which if they're focused on bank lending conditions and things like that, they show some more tightening. The question for us, though, is how significant will that be and how will we be the extent of it, and will be the duration of it? And then once you know that, there's a fair amount of research about how that, with broad uncertainty bands, how that works its way into the economy over what period of time. And so we'll be looking to see the first part of that, how serious is this, and does it look like it's going to be sustained? And if it is, it could easily have a significant macroeconomic effect, and we would factor that into our policy decisions. I mentioned with rate cuts. Rate cuts are not in our base case. And so that's all I have to say. Thank you. Thank you very much.

 For release at 2:00 p.m. EDT March 22, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on March 22, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 4.9 percent, effective March 23, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to direct the Open
 Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed otherwise, to
 execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with the following
 domestic policy directive:
 "Effective March 23, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 4-3/4 to 5 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 5 percent, effective March 23, 2023..In taking this action, the Board approved requests to
 establish that rate submitted by the Boards of Directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of
 Boston, New York, Philadelphia, Richmond, Atlanta, Kansas City, Dallas, and San
 Francisco..(more)

 This information will be updated as appropriate to reflect decisions of the Federal Open Market
 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools
 and approach used to implement monetary policy.
extracted_news_25:
Just days before authorities took control of Silicon Valley Bank on March 10, Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, testified to Congress that he was open to raising interest rates higher and faster in response to data that showed inflation stubbornly embedded within the economy..“For too long, the Federal Reserve has used its claim of independence to thwart Congress and the American people while being unable or unwilling to properly regulate and supervise the large financial institutions under its care,” Scott wrote..ET, to understand how recent bank failures are shaping the central bank's policy approach as the Fed chair works to square the challenge of financial system stress with inflation that remains stubbornly high..Recent disturbances in the banking sector, including last weekend’s emergency takeover of Credit Suisse by UBS, may have given the FOMC some cause for reflection, at least regarding its short term policy..Michael Hewson, chief market analyst at CMC Markets, called that speculation “a ridiculous notion,” and said it would “send the completely the wrong message at a time when optics are everything.”
 He added: If the Fed does have concerns about some parts of the US banking sector, why weren’t they apparent 3 weeks ago when they were pushing the case for keeping a 0.50% rate hike on the table?.“Powell’s challenge in the press conference will be to maintain focus on fighting inflation while signaling flexibility in how they deal with the banking crisis,” Michael Feroli, Chief U.S..“The fall of both SVB and Signature, the near-crash of First Republic, and the struggles of other regional banks shed new light on the systemic important of banks with assets totaling between $100 billion and $250 billion,” the lawmakers wrote in a letter sent Wednesday to Michael Barr, the vice chair for supervision at the Fed..The dozen lawmakers note that the same 2018 rollback of Dodd-Frank gives the Fed latitude in applying tougher regulation on banks in this category – including stronger capital, liquidity, stress testing and resolution plans..“The Fed has a responsibility to ensure financial stability, and in order to fulfill that responsibility, it must ensure that all banks with potential systemic significance are subject to rigorous safety and soundness rules.”
 The lawmakers argue that the federal intervention in the wake of the SVB and Signature failures underscore the systemic risk posed by troubles in banks of this size..Days after the bank failures, the Federal Reserve launched a review of the regulation and oversight of Silicon Valley Bank..That review is being led by Barr, who President Joe Biden nominated to be the Fed’s top regulator of Wall Street..“In order to restore sufficient safety practices to the banking system and restore consumers’ confidence in the soundness of their banks, the Fed must immediately exercise its authority to apply enhanced prudential standards and supervision to banks with $100-$250 billion in assets.”
 Warren has long been a regulation hawk, pushing for tough rules to prevent a repeat of the 2008 crisis and sharply criticizing those who have relaxed rules on banks..‘Serious mistake’
 However, the role of the 2018 rollback of Dodd-Frank in the failure of Silicon Valley Bank is hotly debated
 Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody’s Analytics, recently told CNN’s Kate Bolduan he doesn’t know if the easing of stress test requirements “would have forestalled” the bank failures, adding these stress tests “couldn’t have hurt.”
 Sheila Bair, a Republican and the former chair of the FDIC during the 2008 crisis, told CNN’s Poppy Harlow she doesn’t think there is “some broad problem because of deregulation with regional banks.”
 Patricia McCoy, a former federal regulator, told CNN on Tuesday that the events of the past ten days have shown the 2018 rollback of Dodd-Frank for banks in the $100 billion to $250 billion asset range was a “serious mistake.”
 “Fast forward five years, and two of those banks – Silicon Valley and Signature Bank – failed due to lack of liquidity and possible undercapitalization,” McCoy, now a professor at Boston College Law School, said in an email..“It’s just not easy for them right now.”
 In a note to clients Monday, economists at Goldman Sachs said that while policymakers at the Fed and in Europe have responded aggressively to shore up the global financial system, “markets appear to be less than fully convinced that efforts to support small and midsize banks will prove sufficient.”
 As a result, they wrote, they “think Fed officials will therefore share our view that stress in the banking system remains the most immediate concern for now” and will hold off on another increase..What comes next for the banking industry is largely dependent on the Federal Reserve’s policy decision and whether banks remain above water for the time being..The SVB fiasco provided the first true opportunity to pressure test the supervisory framework established by Dodd-Frank just over 10 years ago, and the results are abysmal.”
 Allianz economist Mohammed El-Erian also gives the Fed low marks in its inflation fight..ET, with Chair Powell’s news conference scheduled for 2:30 p.m.

 settlement of the Federal Reserve's agency MBS transactions.".• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 5 percent, effective March 23, 2023..In taking this action, the Board approved requests to
 establish that rate submitted by the Boards of Directors of the Federal Reserve Banks of

Ayanna Pressley, of Massachusetts, told Politico..“Powell’s challenge in the press conference will be to maintain focus on fighting inflation while signaling flexibility in how they deal with the banking crisis,” Michael Feroli, Chief U.S..During the hearing Powell took questions on a range of topics pertaining to the Federal Reserve's Semi-Annual Monetary Policy Report and the state of the economy..“The fall of both SVB and Signature, the near-crash of First Republic, and the struggles of other regional banks shed new light on the systemic important of banks with assets totaling between $100 billion and $250 billion,” the lawmakers wrote in a letter sent Wednesday to Michael Barr, the vice chair for supervision at the Fed..The dozen lawmakers note that the same 2018 rollback of Dodd-Frank gives the Fed latitude in applying tougher regulation on banks in this category – including stronger capital, liquidity, stress testing and resolution plans..“The Fed has a responsibility to ensure financial stability, and in order to fulfill that responsibility, it must ensure that all banks with potential systemic significance are subject to rigorous safety and soundness rules.”

similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: regulatory, immediate attention, compliance, bank failures, rate cut, financial conditions, balance sheet runoff
2. Second Text: tighter credit conditions, monetary policy, policy firming, inflation to 2 percent, economic activity, economic outlook, interest rate paid on reserve balances

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss monetary policy and its implications for economic conditions.
2. Both texts refer to credit conditions and potential tightening in relation to economic activity.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes compliance and specific regulatory measures in relation to bank performance, whereas the second text focuses on broader monetary policy and its goals, particularly inflation management.
2. The first text conveys a more conversational and informal tone, while the second text presents a formal document style focused on policy decisions.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a qualitative perspective on financial conditions and potential bank behavior following failures, while the second text gives quantitative details on interest rates and specific policy decisions.
2. The first text discusses the review of compliance related to bank operations, whereas the second text comprehensively outlines the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decisions and their implications.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "Bank failures" and "reviews," which are specific to regulatory aspects, while the second text employs "policy firming" and "cumulative tightening," relevant to broader economic strategy.
2. The second text mentions "interest rate paid on reserve balances," a technical term for banking operations, which is not present in the first text.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more negative  
Explanation: The first text conveys a sense of concern and urgency regarding regulatory compliance and the review process, highlighting potential issues within the banking system. Phrases such as "how are you going to ensure that banks comply with these citations take them seriously?" and "there's a real serious review going on" suggest a tone of unease and scrutiny. In contrast, the second text presents developments in a more matter-of-fact manner, using terms like "the Committee anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate," which implies a proactive rather than reactive stance. This indicates a slightly more positive outlook in managing economic conditions.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: lower certainty  
Explanation: The first text exhibits uncertainty regarding future outcomes, particularly with phrases like "I want nothing other than us to find out what happened and why" and "I think that's what you think about." This uncertainty is further emphasized by the mention of "if it is, it could easily have a significant macroeconomic effect," indicating that the speaker is not fully confident about the implications of the current situation. Conversely, the second text reflects a higher level of certainty, using definitive language such as "the Committee will closely monitor incoming information" and "the Committee would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate." This language conveys a strong assurance in the Committee's decision-making process.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: immediate attention, compliance with citations, macroeconomic effect, financial conditions, balance sheet runoff
2. Second Text: Silicon Valley Bank, systemic risk, rollback of Dodd-Frank, reckless interest rate hikes, Congress, financial stability

Similarities:

1. Both texts address the challenges faced by the Federal Reserve in relation to banking regulations and financial conditions in the economy.
2. Both texts discuss the implications of interest rate hikes on economic stability, particularly in the context of recent banking failures.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the review process carried out by the Federal Reserve and the need for compliance with regulations, presenting a more measured tone regarding what actions may be considered in the future.
2. The second text adopts a more critical tone towards the Federal Reserve and its leadership, emphasizing the urgency for regulatory change following the failures of specific banks.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text discusses ongoing reviews and general compliance without delving into specific bank failures or past regulatory rollbacks, while the second text provides detailed accounts of recent banking crises and direct criticisms of specific regulatory failures.
2. The second text outlines precise legislative proposals and criticisms from lawmakers, reflecting a broader scope of political response and consequence compared to the first text's focus on internal reviews and processes.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "vice chair," "review," and "credit conditions," which indicate a procedural focus on internal processes within the Federal Reserve.
2. The second text employs terms such as "systemic risk," "deregulation," and "areas of supervision," reflecting a more political and critical discourse surrounding the Federal Reserve's relationship with the banking sector.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text conveys an overall tone of cautious optimism, particularly when referring to the ongoing review process under Vice Chair Barr’s leadership. Phrases such as "I'm confident that it will produce a satisfactory result" and "I want nothing other than us to find out what happened and why" indicate a hopeful outlook towards resolving the issues at hand. In contrast, the second text is laden with criticism and urgency about the failures of the Federal Reserve, exemplified by statements like "it’s clear we can’t wait any longer for big change at the Fed" and "the Fed had failed in its duty to regulate large financial institutions." This presents a more negative and frustrated emotional bias compared to the first text's stance.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text exhibits a high degree of certainty in its assertions regarding the review process and future outcomes connected to bank regulations, as seen in the repeated use of phrases like "we're always willing to change that if we conclude that it's appropriate" and "there's a fair amount of research about how that works its way into the economy." This conveys confidence in the existence of a systematic approach moving forward. Conversely, the second text reflects a lower certainty level, primarily illustrated by speculative remarks such as "we have seen a series of bank failures" and "it’s likely to result in tighter credit conditions", which imply ambiguity and concerns about the effectiveness of current measures. The language used in the second text indicates an environment of doubt and concerns about regulatory effectiveness.

speech: Good afternoon. Before discussing today's meeting, let me comment briefly on recent developments in the banking sector. Conditions in that sector have broadly improved since early March, and the U.S. banking system is sound and resilient. We will continue to monitor conditions in the sector. We are committed to learning the right lessons from this episode, and we will work to prevent events like these from happening again. As a first step in that process, last week we released Vice Chair for Supervision and Bars review of the Federal Reserve's supervision and regulation of Silicon Valley Bank. The reviews findings underscore the need to address our rules and supervisory practices to make for a stronger and more resilient banking system, and I'm confident that we will do so. From the perspective of monetary policy, our focus remains squarely on our dual mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people. My colleagues and I understand the hardship that high inflation is causing, and we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal. Price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve. Without price stability, the economy does not work for anyone. In particular, without price stability, we will not achieve a sustained period of strong labor market conditions that benefit all. Today, the FOMC raised its policy interest rate by a quarter percentage point. Since early last year, we've raised interest rates by a total of 5 percentage points in order to attain a stance of monetary policy that is sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time. We're also continuing to reduce our securities holdings. Looking ahead, we'll take a data dependent approach in determining the extent to which additional policy-forming may be appropriate. I will have more to say about today's monetary policy actions after briefly reviewing economic developments. The U.S. economy slowed significantly last year, with real GDP rising at a below trend pace of 0.9 percent. The pace of economic growth in the first quarter of this year continued to be modest at 1.1 percent despite a pickup in consumer spending. Activity in the housing sector remains weak, largely reflecting higher mortgage rates. Higher interest rates and slower output growth also appear to be weighing on business-fixed investment. The labor market remains very tight. Over the first three months of the year, job gains averaged 345,000 jobs per month. The unemployment rate remained very low in March at 3.5 percent. Even so, there are some signs that supply and demand in the labor market are coming back into better balance. The labor force participation rate has moved up in recent months, particularly for individuals aged 25 to 54 years. All wage growth has shown some signs of easing and job vacancies have declined so far this year. But overall, labor demands still substantially exceeds the supply of available workers. Inflation remains well above our longer run goal of 2 percent. Over the 12 months ending in March, total PCE prices rose 4.2 percent. Following the volatile food and energy categories, core PCE prices rose 4.6 percent. Inflation has moderated somewhat since the middle of last year. Nonetheless, inflation pressures continue to run high, and the process of getting inflation back down to 2 percent has a long way to go. Despite elevated inflation, longer-term inflation expectations appear to remain well anchored, as reflected in a broad range of surveys of households, businesses, and forecasters, as well as measures from financial markets. The Fed's monetary policy actions are guided by our mandate to promote maximum employment and stable prices for the American people. My colleagues and I are acutely aware that high inflation imposes significant hardship as it erodes purchasing power, especially for those least able to meet the higher costs of essentials, like food, housing, and transportation. We are highly attentive to the risks that high inflation poses to both sides of our mandate, and we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2 percent objective. At today's meeting, the committee raised the target range for the federal funds rate by a quarter percentage point, bringing the target range to 5 to 5 and a quarter percent, and we are continuing to the process of significantly reducing our securities holdings. With today's end.

 The wide range of potential outcomes could provoke divisions among Fed officials, even as they’re expected to raise their benchmark rate to 5.1%, the highest level in 16 years
 Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell walks from the podium after speaking at a news conference at the Federal Reserve on March 22.Alex Brandon/The Associated Press
 Poised to raise interest rates Wednesday for a 10th time, Federal Reserve officials are facing two competing economic trends that could make their future rate decisions more difficult and treacherous..Economists state that after this hike, the FOMC might take a pause and ease up on its monetary policies keeping in mind the banking sector crisis..While equity markets have been jittery this week due to the US banking sector crisis, a pause in rate hikes is not baked into equity markets, according to the analysts at JP Morgan.It will be the tenth rate hike by the FOMC since March 2022, taking the interest rate to 5.25%.Elevated inflation has made the FOMC’s job difficult amidst growing calls by US lawmakers to pause rate hikes, including the likes of Elizabeth Warren and Pramila Jayapaul, who called on the US Fed to “avoid engineering a recession that destroys jobs and crushes small businesses”.Despite this, the broader consensus is that the FOMC may still deliver a 25 bps rate hike before taking a pause.“Even as regional banking sector stress remains in place that is visible in the credit markets, we expect the FOMC to move forward and deliver its final rate hike of 25 bps in the current cycle,” said a report by ICICI Bank.This will take the interest rate to 5.25%, and the total quantum of hikes to 500 basis points since March last year.“We expect the forward guidance to change to indicate that the central bank is moving to a prolonged pause as it waits to assess the lagged effect of monetary tightening,” the ICICI Bank report added.Recent macroeconomic developments in the US have made the FOMC’s job difficult as far as the monetary policy direction is concerned..Taming inflation remains the Fed’s top priority, but even some central bank officials have expressed greater caution in determining additional hikes after the failure of three US regional banks in two months, including the collapse of First Republic Bank on Monday..“At moments like this, of financial stress, the right monetary approach calls for prudence and patience — for assessing the potential impact of financial stress on the real economy,” Austan Goolsbee, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said in a forum last month..At the Fed’s last meeting, officials voted unanimously to raise interest rates by a quarter point, citing data that pointed to persistently high inflation and stronger-than-expected economic activity in the beginning of the year..Swift action from regulators quelled fears of broader financial contagion, and the Fed’s assessment of March’s banking turbulence showed that banks failed because of mismanagement and insufficient enforcement action from regulators..“So if you’re at the Fed and you’re trying to slow the economy, you don’t want the financial system to crash, but it’s OK with you if banks lend a little less, and then you raise interest rates a little less, and that’s why they’ll probably stop after one or two more rate hikes.”
 Tighter credit conditions help the Fed curb demand to bring down inflation.."We expect the Committee to signal that it anticipates pausing in June but retains a hawkish bias, stopping earlier than it initially envisioned because bank stress is likely to cause a tightening of credit.".The central bank may have given a nod toward the possibility in its statement, where it dropped a reference saying it "anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate.”
 But it stopped short of declaring the end to rate hikes, which have already caused cracks in the U.S. banking system and sent stock prices well below their record heights..“A pause in rate actions is therefore appropriate, but further tightening is plausible should inflation prove sticky.”
 Inflation remains well above the Fed's 2% target, and it's still hurting households trying to keep up.."Unless and until the Fed were to see actual strains on the banking sector, we believe it will stick with its stated view from the March meeting that U.S. banks remain sound and resilient.".If the Fed continues to raise rates and doesn't pause, that is only going to create a bigger problem because most of these regional banks are suffering because of the higher rate structure.".What's your call today on how the Fed moves forward with policy?.The Fed’s rate increases over the past 14 months have more than doubled mortgage rates, elevated the costs of auto loans, credit card borrowing and business loans and heightened the risk of a recession..“Inflation remains elevated.”
 The surge in rates has contributed to the collapse of three large banks and turmoil in the banking industry..The Fed's interest rate decision, announced on Wednesday, comes against the backdrop of both still-high inflation and the persistent turmoil in the banking industry.

 Yet, as the Federal Reserve gets ready to make its latest announcement Wednesday afternoon about whether it will raise its key federal funds rate for the 10th consecutive time, financial commentators continue to disagree about how it should respond to economic conditions.."We believe that continuing to raise interest rates would be an abandonment of the Fed’s dual mandate to achieve both maximum employment and price stability and show little regard for the small businesses and working families that will get caught in the wreckage,” they wrote..Follow her on Twitter @daniromerotv

 The wide range of potential outcomes could provoke divisions among Fed officials, even as they’re expected to raise their benchmark rate to 5.1%, the highest level in 16 years
 Federal Reserve Board Chair Jerome Powell walks from the podium after speaking at a news conference at the Federal Reserve on March 22.Alex Brandon/The Associated Press
 Poised to raise interest rates Wednesday for a 10th time, Federal Reserve officials are facing two competing economic trends that could make their future rate decisions more difficult and treacherous..The big question is whether the Fed will also signal Wednesday that it’s now inclined to pause its rate increases – barring any reacceleration of inflation – and keep its key rate unchanged for the rest of 2023 as it assesses its progress in cooling inflation..The Fed wouldn't want to risk financial stability just when inflation is already headed lower,” said Sheth.Amid economic slowdown and banking crisis in the US, crude oil prices have come down significantly in the last one year..Economists state that after this hike, the FOMC might take a pause and ease up on its monetary policies keeping in mind the banking sector crisis..While equity markets have been jittery this week due to the US banking sector crisis, a pause in rate hikes is not baked into equity markets, according to the analysts at JP Morgan.It will be the tenth rate hike by the FOMC since March 2022, taking the interest rate to 5.25%.Elevated inflation has made the FOMC’s job difficult amidst growing calls by US lawmakers to pause rate hikes, including the likes of Elizabeth Warren and Pramila Jayapaul, who called on the US Fed to “avoid engineering a recession that destroys jobs and crushes small businesses”.Despite this, the broader consensus is that the FOMC may still deliver a 25 bps rate hike before taking a pause.“Even as regional banking sector stress remains in place that is visible in the credit markets, we expect the FOMC to move forward and deliver its final rate hike of 25 bps in the current cycle,” said a report by ICICI Bank.This will take the interest rate to 5.25%, and the total quantum of hikes to 500 basis points since March last year.“We expect the forward guidance to change to indicate that the central bank is moving to a prolonged pause as it waits to assess the lagged effect of monetary tightening,” the ICICI Bank report added.Recent macroeconomic developments in the US have made the FOMC’s job difficult as far as the monetary policy direction is concerned..While retail inflation in the US fell for the ninth consecutive month to 5% in March, it is still above the Fed’s target of 2%.Multinational bank ING said in a note that “inflation remains unacceptably high, but banking stresses are leading to a tightening of lending conditions.”Wage inflation, too, has remained robust, which is feeding demand-side inflation – the average hourly earnings increased from 4.4% in January to 4.6% in February..ING expects rate cuts to begin as soon as November this year.Analysts at Nomura also note that a 25 bps hike is likely on Wednesday, but going forward, the monetary policy tightening could come to an end.“There appears to have been uptake in emergency borrowings at the San Francisco Fed region, even after adjusting for the impact of quantitative tightening, which might be related to continued news of stress at the First Republic Bank,” the brokerage said, adding that it expects rate cuts to start in March 2024.All in all, the consensus is that the FOMC is highly likely to deliver one last 25 bps rate hike today while keeping a close watch on inflation..Taming inflation remains the Fed’s top priority, but even some central bank officials have expressed greater caution in determining additional hikes after the failure of three US regional banks in two months, including the collapse of First Republic Bank on Monday..“At moments like this, of financial stress, the right monetary approach calls for prudence and patience — for assessing the potential impact of financial stress on the real economy,” Austan Goolsbee, president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago, said in a forum last month..At the Fed’s last meeting, officials voted unanimously to raise interest rates by a quarter point, citing data that pointed to persistently high inflation and stronger-than-expected economic activity in the beginning of the year..Swift action from regulators quelled fears of broader financial contagion, and the Fed’s assessment of March’s banking turbulence showed that banks failed because of mismanagement and insufficient enforcement action from regulators..“So if you’re at the Fed and you’re trying to slow the economy, you don’t want the financial system to crash, but it’s OK with you if banks lend a little less, and then you raise interest rates a little less, and that’s why they’ll probably stop after one or two more rate hikes.”
 Tighter credit conditions help the Fed curb demand to bring down inflation.."Strains in the banking sector continue to cause headaches at the Fed, while the Treasury worries about the debt limit," SocGen's Kit Juckes wrote.."We expect the Committee to signal that it anticipates pausing in June but retains a hawkish bias, stopping earlier than it initially envisioned because bank stress is likely to cause a tightening of credit.".In the portion of the statement where the Fed provides guidance, Mericle expects to see a sentence that could look something like, "The Committee anticipates that the stance of monetary policy will most likely be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time but will closely monitor incoming information and assess the implications for monetary policy.".The central bank may have given a nod toward the possibility in its statement, where it dropped a reference saying it "anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate.”
 But it stopped short of declaring the end to rate hikes, which have already caused cracks in the U.S. banking system and sent stock prices well below their record heights..“A pause in rate actions is therefore appropriate, but further tightening is plausible should inflation prove sticky.”
 Inflation remains well above the Fed's 2% target, and it's still hurting households trying to keep up.."Unless and until the Fed were to see actual strains on the banking sector, we believe it will stick with its stated view from the March meeting that U.S. banks remain sound and resilient.".If the Fed continues to raise rates and doesn't pause, that is only going to create a bigger problem because most of these regional banks are suffering because of the higher rate structure.".What's your call today on how the Fed moves forward with policy?.The Fed’s rate increases over the past 14 months have more than doubled mortgage rates, elevated the costs of auto loans, credit card borrowing and business loans and heightened the risk of a recession..“Inflation remains elevated.”
 The surge in rates has contributed to the collapse of three large banks and turmoil in the banking industry..“We should gather further data and be careful about raising rates too aggressively.”
 Advertisement
 Likewise, Patrick Harker, president of the Philadelphia Fed, warned against overdoing rate hikes and possibly derailing the economy..The Fed's interest rate decision, announced on Wednesday, comes against the backdrop of both still-high inflation and the persistent turmoil in the banking industry.
similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: sound and resilient, dual mandate, high inflation, labor market conditions, unemployment rate, core PCE prices, wage growth, labor demands, purchasing power
2. Second Text: tighter credit conditions, cumulative tightening, economic activity and inflation, monetary policy implementation, open market operations, primary credit rate, effective May 4, 2023

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's policies and actions concerning interest rates.
2. Both texts acknowledge the challenges posed by inflation and its impact on the economy.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text places significant emphasis on the current state of the banking sector and the importance of adapting regulations, while the second text is more focused on specific monetary policy actions and operational details.
2. The first text discusses broader economic indicators and labor market conditions, while the second text emphasizes the technical aspects of monetary policy implementation.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a more comprehensive analysis of economic conditions, including GDP growth and consumer spending, whereas the second text focuses on the meeting's procedural outcomes and upcoming actions.
2. The first text discusses the socio-economic implications of inflation, detailing its effect on purchasing power, while the second text lacks this qualitative economic context and is more technical in nature.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "price stability," "inflation expectations," and "job gains," while the second text introduces phrases such as "dollar roll transactions," "coupon swap transactions," and "effective May 4, 2023," which are not present in the first text.
2. The first text refers to "employment" and "economic growth," while the second text uses different terminology focused on "credit conditions" and the "Board of Governors' decisions."
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text generally conveys a more optimistic tone through phrases such as "broadly improved," "the U.S. banking system is sound and resilient," and "I'm confident that we will do so." These phrases exhibit a subtle positivity regarding the banking sector and a proactive commitment to addressing challenges. In contrast, the second text predominantly presents a more neutral or cautious outlook, indicated by phrases like "inflation remains elevated" and "tighter credit conditions... are likely to weigh on economic activity." While it acknowledges risks, it lacks the forward-looking confidence that characterizes the first text. 

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text shows a higher level of certainty through definitive statements such as "we will continue to monitor conditions," "we are committed to learning the right lessons," and "we remain strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal." These statements express assurance in the Federal Reserve's plans and actions. On the other hand, the second text includes more hedging language, like "would be prepared to adjust" and "likely to weigh on economic activity," indicating a lower level of confidence in outcomes and a more tentative approach. This distinction reflects that the first text conveys a stronger conviction in its assessments and decisions compared to the more cautious language of the second text.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: monetary policy, dual mandate, price stability, PCE prices, job gains, labor market participation
2. Second Text: central bank, battling inflation, cumulative tightening, credit conditions, economic fragility, pause in rate hikes

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's focus on inflation and the measures it is taking in response.
2. Both texts address the challenges posed by the current economic conditions, specifically regarding the banking sector and its impact on monetary policy decisions.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes a proactive stance from the Federal Reserve, focusing on the commitment to managing inflation and ensuring a stable financial system, with a tone of confidence. 
2. The second text reflects a sense of caution and uncertainty, highlighting the potential for the Fed to pause rate increases due to ongoing banking issues and political pressures.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides detailed statistics on economic growth, inflation rates, and labor market conditions, giving a comprehensive view of the economy's current state. 
2. The second text focuses more on recent banking turmoil, the considerations around pausing rate hikes, and political influences, offering a narrower analysis of the immediate context affecting monetary policy.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "FOMC," "maximum employment," and "policy interest rate," which are specific to the Fed's structure and goals.
2. The second text refers to "animal spirits," "credit conditions," and "recession," which relate more to market psychology and the broader implications of monetary policy decisions.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text conveys a slightly more positive emotional bias compared to the second text. Phrases such as "conditions in that sector have broadly improved" and "the U.S. banking system is sound and resilient" indicate optimism regarding the financial system's recovery and stability. Additionally, the text expresses confidence in the actions being taken to address inflation with phrases like "I’m confident that we will do so" and "we are strongly committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2 percent goal." In contrast, the second text reflects a more cautious sentiment with statements like "the Fed is still battling inflation," "remain well above the Fed’s 2% target," and "concerns that the Fed might have to further tighten credit." These phrases denote a more negative outlook and signal a struggle in achieving economic goals.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text demonstrates a higher level of certainty than the second text. It clearly asserts the Federal Reserve's goals and commitments, for example, stating "we are committed to learning the right lessons" and "price stability is the responsibility of the Federal Reserve." This language signals strong conviction in the Federal Reserve's actions and future policies. Conversely, the second text expresses a lower level of certainty, with phrases such as "the big question is whether the Fed will also signal Wednesday" and "could weaken the economy if…" suggesting speculation and indecision about the Fed's future actions. These elements contribute to a more ambiguous outlook, contrasting the decisiveness presented in the first text.

speech: We have raised interest rates by five percentage points in a little more than a year. We are seeing the effects of our policy tightening on demand in the most interest rate sensitive sectors of the economy, particularly housing and investment. It will take time, however, for the full effects of monetary restraint to be realized, especially on inflation. In addition, the economy is likely to face further headwinds from tighter credit conditions. Credit conditions had already been tightening over the past year or so in response to our policy actions and a softer economic outlook. But the strains that emerged in the banking sector in early March appear to be resulting in even tighter credit conditions for households and businesses. In turn, these tighter credit conditions are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation. The extent of these effects remains uncertain. In light of these uncertain headwinds, along with monetary policy restraint we've put in place, our future policy actions will depend on how events unfold. In determining the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate to return inflation to 2% over time, the committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and inflation, and economic and financial developments. We will make that determination meeting by meeting based on the totality of incoming data and their implications for the outlook for economic activity and inflation. We are prepared to do more if greater monetary policy restraint is warranted. We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2% goal and to keep our longer term inflation expectations well anchored. Increasing inflation is likely to require a period of below trend growth and some softening of labor market conditions. Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run. To conclude, we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country. Everything we do is in service to our public mission. We at the Fed will do everything we can to achieve our maximum employment and price stability goals. Thank you. I look forward to your questions. Thanks, Deena. Hi, Gina Smyla. Can you our times? Thanks for taking our questions. I wonder if you could tell us whether we should read the statement today as a suggestion that the committee is prepared to pause interest rate increases in June. I also wonder if the Fed staff has in any way revised their forecast for a mild recession from the March minutes. If so, what a recession like what they're envisioning would look and feel like when it comes to, for example, the unemployment rate. So taking your question, of course, today our decision was to raise the federal funds rate by 25 basis points. A decision on a pause was not made today. We will have noticed that in the statement from March, we had a sentence that said the committee anticipates that some additional policy firming may be appropriate. That sentence is not in the statement anymore. We took that out and instead we're saying that in determining the extent to which additional policy firming may be appropriate to return inflation at 2% over time, the committee will take into account certain factors. That's a meaningful change that we're no longer saying that we anticipate. We'll be driven by incoming data, meeting by meeting and we'll approach that question at the June meeting. So the staff's forecast is, so let me say start by saying that that's not my own most likely case, which is really that the economy will continue to grow at a modest rate this year. And I think that's so different people in the committee have different forecasts. That's my own assessment of the most likely path. Staff produces its own forecast and it's independent of the forecasts of the participants, which include the governors and the reserve bank presidents of course. And we think this is a healthy thing that the staff is writing down what they really think they're not especially influenced by what the governors think and vice versa. The governors are not taking what the staff says and just writing that down. So it's actually good that the staff and individual participants can have different perspectives. So broadly, the forecast was for a mild recession and by that I would characterize as one in which the rising unemployment is smaller than has been typical in modern era recessions. I wouldn't want to characterize the staff's forecast for this meeting. We'll leave that to the minutes. But broadly, broadly similar to that.

 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy
 stance announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on May 3, 2023:
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to raise the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances to 5.15 percent, effective May 4, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to direct the Open
 Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed otherwise, to
 execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with the following
 domestic policy directive:
 "Effective May 4, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to:
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 5 to 5-1/4 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve a 1/4 percentage point increase in the primary credit rate to
 5.25 percent, effective May 4, 2023.

tightening,” the ICICI Bank report added.Recent macroeconomic developments in the US have made the FOMC’s job difficult as far as the monetary policy direction is concerned..While retail inflation in the US fell for the ninth consecutive month to 5% in March, it is still above the Fed’s target of 2%.Multinational bank ING said in a note that “inflation remains unacceptably high, but banking stresses are leading to a tightening of lending conditions.”Wage inflation, too, has remained robust, which is feeding demand-side inflation – the average hourly earnings increased from 4.4% in January to 4.6% in February..At the Fed’s last meeting, officials voted unanimously to raise interest rates by a quarter point, citing data that pointed to persistently high inflation and stronger-than-expected economic activity in the beginning of the year..“So if you’re at the Fed and you’re trying to slow the economy, you don’t want the financial system to crash, but it’s OK with you if banks lend a little less, and then you raise interest rates a little less, and that’s why they’ll probably stop after one or two more rate hikes.”
 Tighter credit conditions help the Fed curb demand to bring down inflation.."We expect the Committee to signal that it anticipates pausing in June but retains a hawkish bias, stopping earlier than it initially envisioned because bank stress is likely to cause a tightening of credit.".In the portion of the statement where the Fed provides guidance, Mericle expects to see a sentence that could look something like, "The Committee anticipates that the stance of monetary policy will most likely be sufficiently restrictive to return inflation to 2 percent over time but will closely monitor incoming information and assess the implications for monetary policy.".The move was widely expected, and it’s supposed to slow the economy further in hopes of getting inflation under control..“A pause in rate actions is therefore appropriate, but further tightening is plausible should inflation prove sticky.”
 Inflation remains well above the Fed's 2% target, and it's still hurting households trying to keep up..If the Fed continues to raise rates and doesn't pause, that is only going to create a bigger problem because most of these regional banks are suffering because of the higher rate structure.".“Even if this proves to be the final Fed rate hike, interest rates are still high and will remain that way.”
 What’s happening with credit cards?.What's your call today on how the Fed moves forward with policy?.The Fed’s rate increases over the past 14 months have more than doubled mortgage rates, elevated the costs of auto loans, credit card borrowing and business loans and heightened the risk of a recession..“Inflation remains elevated.”
 The surge in rates has contributed to the collapse of three large banks and turmoil in the banking industry..Chair Jerome Powell had said in March that a cutback in lending by banks, to shore up their finances, could act as the equivalent of a quarter-point rate hike in slowing the economy..Fed economists have estimated that tighter credit resulting from the bank failures will contribute to a “mild recession” later this year, thereby raising the pressure on the central bank to suspend its rate hikes..“We should gather further data and be careful about raising rates too aggressively.”

 Likewise, Patrick Harker, president of the Philadelphia Fed, warned against overdoing rate hikes and possibly derailing the economy.

 5.25 percent, effective May 4, 2023..-2-

 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools

similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: monetary policy restraint, future policy actions, economic activity and inflation, price stability, maximum employment, uncertainties in the banking sector, lags with which monetary policy affects, mild recession.
2. Second Text: target range for the federal funds rate, economic outlook, inflation pressures and expectations, primary credit rate, unanimous vote, open market operations, household and business credit conditions.

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the raising of interest rates as a measure to combat inflation.
2. Both emphasize the importance of monitoring economic activity and inflation in determining future monetary policy actions.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text has a more conversational tone and includes a question-answer component, providing insights into specific economic outlooks and the Fed's decision-making process. The second text is more formal and focused on the decisions made within specific monetary policy frameworks.
2. The first text elaborates on the uncertainties surrounding the economy, particularly in relation to inflation and banking sector strains, while the second text is more focused on the technical details of monetary policy implementation.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides broader context on the economic implications of tighter credit conditions and the Fed’s commitment to public service goals, whereas the second text is more detailed regarding the specific actions taken and the processes involved in decision-making.
2. The second text includes information about the voting members of the Federal Reserve and operational policies, which the first text does not mention.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "cumulative tightening of monetary policy" and "softening of labor market conditions," while the second text refers to "target range for the federal funds rate" and "primary credit rate."
2. The first text includes phrases like "maximum employment and stable prices," whereas the second text emphasizes "unanimous vote" and "open market operations."
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text conveys a subtly more positive emotional bias compared to the second text. Phrases such as "We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2% goal" and "Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run" reflect a sense of optimism and determination. In contrast, the second text features phrases like "Inflation remains elevated" and "Tighter credit conditions... are likely to weigh on economic activity," which are more neutral and highlight challenges without an optimistic outlook. The first text's overall tone emphasizes hope and dedication to objectives, presenting a more positive emotional stance regarding the Federal Reserve's actions and goals.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text exhibits a higher level of certainty compared to the second text. Phrases such as "We will make that determination meeting by meeting based on the totality of incoming data" and "We are prepared to do more if greater monetary policy restraint is warranted" indicate a strong confidence in responding to economic changes. On the other hand, the second text features a more moderate level of certainty with statements like "The Committee will closely monitor incoming information and assess the implications," which reflects a watchful approach rather than proactive certainty. The first text's definitive language suggests stronger confidence in the decision-making process, while the second text's wording implies a need for ongoing assessment and adjustment.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: policy tightening, monetary restraint, economic activity, maximum employment, inflation expectations, cumulative tightening
2. Second Text: aggressively raising rates, personal pain for households, cool inflation, debt ceiling, “mild recession,” rate cuts, financially stressed banks

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's actions related to interest rates and their impacts on inflation and the economy.
2. Both emphasize the precarious balance the Fed must strike between controlling inflation and avoiding significant negative impacts on economic growth and employment.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the technical aspects of monetary policy and its effects on the economy and inflation, with a more formal tone.
2. The second text highlights the personal impacts on households and the potential political ramifications of monetary policy decisions, offering a less formal perspective.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a detailed breakdown of monetary policy mechanics and future considerations, such as meeting-by-meeting analysis and the importance of data.
2. The second text emphasizes the broader context of socio-political pressures and the immediate effects on consumers and the banking sector without delving deeply into technicalities.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "cumulative tightening" and "policy firming," which are more specific to economic jargon.
2. The second text includes terms like "debt ceiling," "personal pain for households," and "financially stressed banks," which relate to current events and public sentiment.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text emphasizes a commitment to achieving economic stability and maintaining public trust, using phrases like "We remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2% goal" and "Restoring price stability is essential to set the stage for achieving maximum employment and stable prices over the longer run." These phrases convey a sense of determination and forward-looking optimism. The second text, on the other hand, contains more expressions of caution and concern, such as "the Fed knows it’s pushing rates to an uncomfortable level" and references to "concerns that the Fed might have to further tighten credit to slow price increases." While both texts touch on similar issue areas, the first text presents a more hopeful outlook focused on policy goals, while the second text highlights the potential negative ramifications of the Fed’s actions, indicating a slight tendency toward pessimism.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text presents the Fed's actions and policies with a strong level of assurance. Phrases like "we are prepared to do more if greater monetary policy restraint is warranted" and "we will make that determination meeting by meeting based on the totality of incoming data" show a clear commitment to respond decisively based on economic conditions, reflecting high certainty about the Fed's approach. The second text, however, includes more uncertainties and speculation about the effects of rate hikes, mentioning "the big question is whether the Fed will also signal Wednesday that it’s now inclined to pause its rate increases" and the potential for a "deep enough recession." This language reflects a lower level of assurance in the outcomes of policy decisions, indicating that the second text communicates a more cautious perspective.

speech: Thank you, Chair Powell, for the seagull from the Washington Post. Thanks for taking our questions. I'm wondering if you can talk about the account of possible effects of a debt limit stand off. You said repeatedly that the ceiling must be raised. But do you see any economics effects of even getting close to a default and what type of situation would that look like? So I wouldn't want to speculate specifically, but I will say this. These are fiscal policy matters for starters, and they're for Congress and the administration for the elected parts of the government to deal with, and they're really consigned to them. From our standpoint, I would just say this. It's essential that the debt ceiling be raised in a timely way so that the U.S. government can pay all of its bills when they're due. A failure to do that would be unprecedented. We'd be in uncharted territory and the consequences to the U.S. economy would be highly uncertain and could be quite averse. So I'll just leave it there. We don't give advice to either side. We just would point out that it's very important that this be done. The other point I'll make about that though is that no one should assume that the Fed can protect the economy from the potential short and long-term effects of a failure to pay our bills on time. It would be so uncertain that it's just as important that this – we never get to a place where we're actually talking about or even having a situation where the U.S. government's not paying its bills. And just to follow up, was discussion around the uncertainty of a possible standoff? Did that affect today's monetary policy decision at all? I wouldn't say that it did. It was – of course, it's something that came up. We talk a lot about risks to the outlook and that will – that come up – a number of people did raise that as a risk to the outlook. I wouldn't say that it was important in today's monetary policy decision yet. Steve. Oh, thank you, Yemen. Steve Leigh's been CNBC. Can you tell us what the Federal Reserve Board did in the wake of that February presentation where you will inform that Silicon Valley Bank and other banks were experiencing interest rate risks? Can you tell me what supervisory actions you've done in the wake of the recent bank failures to make sure that banks are currently appropriately managing interest rate risk? And kind of part three, but it's all the same question here. Do you still think this separation principle that monetary policy at supervision can be handled with different tools? Thank you. Sure. So, the February 14 presentation, I didn't remember it very well, but now, of course, I've gone back and looked at it very carefully. I did remember it. And what it was was a general presentation. It was an informational briefing of the whole board, the entire board. I think all members were there. And it was about interest rate risk in the banks and lots of data. And there was one page on Silicon Valley Bank which talked about the amount of losses they are marked to market losses they had in their portfolio. There was nothing in it about that I recall anyway about the risk of a bank run. So it was, I think, the takeaway was they were going a way to do an assessment of vertical, sorry, a horizontal assessment of banks. It wasn't presented as an urgent or alarming situation. It was presented as an informational, non-decision kind of a thing. And I thought it was a good presentation. And as I said, did remember it. In terms of what we're doing, of course, I think banks themselves, or many, many banks, are now attending to liquidity and taking opportunity now, really, since the events of early March to build liquidity. And you asked about the separation principle. You know, like so many things, it's very useful. But ultimately, it has its limits. I mean, I think in this particular case, we have found that the monetary policy tools and the financial stability tools are not in conflict. They're both working well together. We've used our financial stability tools to support banks through our lending facilities. And at the same time, we've been able to use our monetary policy tools to foster maximum employment and price stability. Mr. Chairman, I'm sorry. I don't need to be argumentative, but the staff report said S.V.B. has significant interest rate risk. It said interest rate risk measurements failed at S.V.B. And it said banks with large unrealized losses faced significant safety and soundness risk. Why was that not alarming? Well, I mean, I didn't say it wasn't alarming. It was, they're pointing out something that they're working on and that they're on the case that, you know, that I'm not sure whether they mentioned, I think they did actually. They mentioned that they had taken regulatory
