extracted_news_25:
The 18 committee members appear split between those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is for at least a few months and see whether inflation further moderates..The Fed’s goal is to achieve the delicate task of slowing borrowing and spending enough to cool growth and tame inflation, without derailing the economy in the process..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 After inflation cooled, investors are expecting a pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hiking campaign that has pushed interest rates to the highest level since 2007..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 The Federal Reserve’s likely decision Wednesday afternoon to leave interest rates alone for the first time in 11 meetings will raise hopes that it may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking campaign to cool inflation..“That might mean the Fed is going to have to hold rates higher for longer, and it may even mean boosting rates further in the months ahead,” McBride said..For the Fed to leave rates alone, at least for now, "gives them a little bit of time to evaluate the broader economic and inflationary landscape to see if further rate hikes are warranted.”
 ___
 AP Auto Writer Tom Krisher in Detroit contributed to this report..By making it more expensive to borrow and invest, the Fed has been working to slow the overall demand in the economy and thus reduce upward price pressure..That’s a big deal to Fed officials who have spoken publicly about their fears of a wage-price spiral — the feedback loop that drives inflation higher as people make more money and go out and spend it..During the Fed policy meeting in May, participants expressed worry that even though the pace of wage growth has been gradually slowing, it’s still “running at a pace that, given current estimates of trend productivity growth, was well above what would be consistent over the longer run with the Committee’s 2% inflation objective,” according to minutes from the meeting..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a “hawkish skip.”
 While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00 per cent-5.25 per cent range, Fed policy-makers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..The expected policy outcome reflects a compromise born of some uncertainty around what it all means, with those Fed officials worried the economy may weaken fast getting at least a six-week timeout until the July 25-26 meeting, and those concerned about still-high inflation readings knowing the central bank will remain primed to move rates higher if price pressures do not relent..The Fed’s last set of quarterly projections anticipated the benchmark overnight interest rate would only move down by the end of 2024 as inflation also declined – movements that keep the inflation-adjusted rate of interest roughly the same..Market participants expect the U.S. central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to pause interest rate hikes because of uncertainty over the economic outlook and the lagged effects of 10 rate increases since March 2022..“Looking ahead, nearly all Committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down 2% over time,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting news conference..“The Fed is putting more weight on the strong jobs data and sticky core inflation than the slowing headline inflation numbers and is clearly trying to avoid a 1970s style resurgence in inflation,” wrote Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management, in an analyst note..“The Fed had to do something to knock market optimism today, otherwise it risks a tougher inflation fight and deeper economic woes down the line.”
 Although the Fed thinks additional policy action is necessary to successfully tamp down inflation, Powell said he’s optimistic about inflation cooling further because of slowing shelter costs, which make up more than 40% of the Consumer Price Index’s core measure..“I think any forecast that people are making right now about inflation coming down this year will contain a big dose — this year or next year — will contain a good amount of disinflation from that source.”
 Tighter access to credit
 Officials are also keeping a close watch on how credit conditions shape up, considering some lingering stress in the regional banking sector..“We expect Powell will follow up with a relatively hawkish tone in the press conference in order to prevent a dovish market reaction, stressing that inflation is still too high and the Fed will be resolute in returning inflation to target.”
 Wall Street’s “fear gauge” — the Cboe Volatility Index — dropped back below 15, against an average of 23 for the past year, underscoring support for risk assets..Most Read from Bloomberg Businessweek
 ©2023 Bloomberg L.P.
 
 
 Something of a neutral report on consumer-level inflation in the U.S. economy should give the Federal Reserve reason to pump the brakes on additional rate hikes for now, analysts said Tuesday..The Fed has battled high inflation for the better part of a year with successive rate hikes that are designed to make borrowing prohibitive enough to dampen demand and pull consumer-level prices lower..The Fed is presented with a careful balancing act with rate hikes, trying to both cool the economy and avoid a recession that would see widespread layoffs..It’s attempting the excruciating balancing act of slowing the economy just enough through rate increases to snuff out high inflation, but not so much as to break the job market and create a recession..Greedflation may force the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates “higher for longer” to fight inflation, pushing the economy into recession..“Analysts reveling in companies’ higher margins at the micro level have not realized the macroeconomic implications of greedflation,” he wrote on Wednesday, explaining that rising profits have driven inflation “higher for longer,” which, in turn, will force the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates elevated “and hence the coming recession will be deeper for longer.”
 For over a year now Wall Street economists have warned that rising interest rates will eventually bring the economy to a standstill and spark a recession, but so far their predictions have proved—at the very least—to be premature..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a "hawkish skip."

 and businesses are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation..The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of

 WASHINGTON (AP) — The Federal Reserve, having raised interest rates at the fastest pace in four decades, is poised Wednesday to leave rates alone for the first time in 15 months to allow time to gauge the impact of its aggressive drive to tame inflation..The 18 committee members appear split between those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is for at least a few months and see whether inflation further moderates..The Fed’s goal is to achieve the delicate task of slowing borrowing and spending enough to cool growth and tame inflation, without derailing the economy in the process..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’

 Although the Fed thinks additional policy action is necessary to successfully tamp down inflation, Powell said he’s optimistic about inflation cooling further because of slowing shelter costs, which make up more than 40% of the Consumer Price Index’s core measure..“I think any forecast that people are making right now about inflation coming down this year will contain a big dose — this year or next year — will contain a good amount of disinflation from that source.”
 Tighter access to credit
 Officials are also keeping a close watch on how credit conditions shape up, considering some lingering stress in the regional banking sector..“We expect Powell will follow up with a relatively hawkish tone in the press conference in order to prevent a dovish market reaction, stressing that inflation is still too high and the Fed will be resolute in returning inflation to target.”
 Wall Street’s “fear gauge” — the Cboe Volatility Index — dropped back below 15, against an average of 23 for the past year, underscoring support for risk assets..Most Read from Bloomberg Businessweek

 Something of a neutral report on consumer-level inflation in the U.S. economy should give the Federal Reserve reason to pump the brakes on additional rate hikes for now, analysts said Tuesday..Core inflation increased by at 5.3% over the 12-month period to May, File photo by Ken Cedeno/UPI | License Photo
 June 13 (UPI) -- The Federal Reserve on Wednesday is expected to pump the brakes on additional rate hikes, for now, following something of a neutral report on consumer-level inflation in the U.S. economy..The Fed has battled high inflation for the better part of a year with successive rate hikes that are designed to make borrowing prohibitive enough to dampen demand and pull consumer-level prices lower..The Fed is presented with a careful balancing act with rate hikes, trying to both cool the economy and avoid a recession that would see widespread layoffs..It’s attempting the excruciating balancing act of slowing the economy just enough through rate increases to snuff out high inflation, but not so much as to break the job market and create a recession..Greedflation may force the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates “higher for longer” to fight inflation, pushing the economy into recession..“Analysts reveling in companies’ higher margins at the micro level have not realized the macroeconomic implications of greedflation,” he wrote on Wednesday, explaining that rising profits have driven inflation “higher for longer,” which, in turn, will force the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates elevated “and hence the coming recession will be deeper for longer.”
 For over a year now Wall Street economists have warned that rising interest rates will eventually bring the economy to a standstill and spark a recession, but so far their predictions have proved—at the very least—to be premature..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a "hawkish skip.".While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00%-5.25% range, Fed policymakers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..While inflation is still double the Fed’s target range, the slowdown has the majority of analysts predicting the Fed won’t lift rates tonight.."The soft inflation report effectively cements a Fed pause, although I doubt it will be enough to warrant a dovish undertone as it's not in their interest with CPI twice the Fed's target," said Matt Simpson, senior market analyst at City Index, who points to 103 as a key support level for the dollar index.
similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: mandate, high inflation imposes hardship, purchasing power, monetary restraint, target range for the federal funds rate, maximum employment and price stability goals, economic headwinds, policy tightening, cumulative tightening of monetary policy, longer-term inflation expectations
2. Second Text: inflation pressures, target range for the federal funds rate, economic outlook, voting for the monetary policy action, unanimous vote, decisions regarding monetary policy implementation, primary credit rate, open market operations

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's commitment to managing inflation and maintaining maximum employment.
2. Both reference the target range for the federal funds rate and the effects of monetary policy on economic activity and inflation.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes the hardship faced by individuals due to high inflation and includes personal impacts, while the second text is more technical and focused on operational decisions and the mechanics of monetary policy.
2. The first text explores the uncertainties and lag effects of monetary policy decisions, whereas the second text directly states the decisions made regarding interest rates without the same depth of uncertainty discussion.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a more in-depth narrative on the rationale and implications of current monetary policy and discusses participant projections for the federal funds rate, whereas the second text summarizes decisions and member voting without extensive rationale.
2. The first text includes more qualitative assessments regarding upcoming expectations, such as the potential for below-trend growth, which is less emphasized in the second text.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses phrases like "softening of labor market conditions" and "returning inflation to our 2% goal," while the second text uses "inflation pressures" and "adjust the stance of monetary policy."
2. The first text discusses the "Federal Open Market Committee" in more detail, while the second text lists individual committee members and their voting actions explicitly.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: Slightly more positive  
Explanation: The first text reflects a slightly more positive emotional bias compared to the second text. This is evident in phrases where the speaker emphasizes commitment to goals, such as "we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2% objective" and "we will do everything we can to achieve our maximum employment and price stability goals." These expressions convey a sense of actionable optimism and dedication that is less pronounced in the second text, which primarily states, "The Committee seeks to achieve maximum employment and inflation at the rate of 2 percent over the longer run," a comparatively more matter-of-fact and less impassioned statement.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: Higher certainty  
Explanation: The first text expresses higher certainty in its assertions and plans compared to the second text. The phrase "we have been seeing the effects of our policy tightening" indicates confidence in observing the results of their actions, which contrasts with the second text's "are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation," expressing a less definitive stance. Additionally, the first text mentions "nearly all committee participants expect that it will be appropriate to raise interest rates somewhat further," clearly stating expectations, while the second text uses qualifying language with "would be prepared to adjust" which suggests a more tentative approach.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: maximum employment, stable prices, policy tightening, cumulative tightening
2. Second Text: hawkish skip, greedflation, interest rate hikes, gauge the impact

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's interest rates and its impact on inflation.
2. Each text emphasizes the delicate balance the Federal Reserve must maintain between controlling inflation and sustaining economic growth.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on the deliberate and cautious approach of the Federal Reserve regarding monetary policy, portraying a formal tone and in-depth analysis of projections and decision-making processes.
2. The second text adopts a more immediate, journalistic style, concentrating on the latest developments regarding rates and public sentiment, with a tone suggesting urgency and speculation about future moves.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides a comprehensive examination of the Federal Reserve's actions and the rationale behind maintaining interest rates, including projected numbers for future rates.
2. The second text highlights specific terms like "hawkish skip" and "greedflation," emphasizing ongoing concerns about inflation while presenting less detailed projections.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "softening of labor market conditions" and "longer-term inflation expectations," which are more quantitative and technical.
2. The second text includes phrases such as "hawkish skip" and "greedflation," which are more casual and indicative of ongoing market trends and sentiments.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text conveys a commitment to achieving economic stability, reflecting an emotionally positive stance toward the potential for recovery and effective monetary policy. Phrases like "we are strongly committed to returning inflation to our 2% objective" and "we understand that our actions affect communities, families, and businesses across the country" illustrate an active and optimistic engagement with the challenges faced. In contrast, the second text has a slightly more cautious tone, with phrases such as "the Fed is putting more weight on the strong jobs data and sticky core inflation" and "greedflation may force the Federal Reserve to keep interest rates higher for longer," which indicate a focus on potential negative outcomes and a more pessimistic perspective on economic conditions.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text demonstrates a higher level of certainty regarding the Fed's actions and their anticipated outcomes. For instance, statements like "we remain committed to bringing inflation back down to our 2% goal" clearly express confidence in the Fed’s ability to meet its targets. In contrast, the second text conveys a more uncertain stance, illustrated by phrases such as "those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is" and "a careful balancing act with rate hikes," indicating a lack of consensus and a degree of hesitation about future actions. This suggests that the first text is more assertive in its declarations and commitments compared to the second, which is more exploratory and cautious.

speech: consecutive 75 basis point hikes we moderated to a pace of 50 basis point hikes and then this year to 325 basis point hikes at sequential meetings. So it seemed to us to make obvious sense to moderate our rate hikes as we got closer to our destination. So the decision to consider not hiking at every meeting and ultimately to hold rate steady at this meeting, I would just say it's a continuation of that process. The main issue that we're focused on now is determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate to return inflation to 2% over time. So the pace of the increases and the ultimate level of increases are separate variables. Given how far we have come, it may make sense for rates to move higher but at a more moderate pace. I want to stress one more thing and that is that the committee decision made today was only about this meeting. We didn't make any decision about going forward including what would happen at the next meeting including we did not decide or really discuss anything about going to an every other meeting kind of an approach or really any other approach. We really were focused on what to do at this meeting. So there was no kind of initial debate about the possibility of July any sense of the initial support at this stage for that move. So again we didn't we didn't make a decision about July. I mean of course it came up in the meeting from time to time but really the focus was on what to do today. I would say about July two things. One decision hasn't been made to. I do expect that it will be a live meeting. Thanks Howard Schneider with Reuters. I wish this morning if you could help us understand the narrative here because it feels like there's been a level shift in the dots. Stronger GDP less of a hit on employment, slower progress on inflation and I'm wondering in this sort of where's the disinflation coming from? The labor market is going to be stronger. It looks like it's not coming from there. Demand is not coming down all that fast according to GDP. You've doubled your estimate of GDP. So what's the narrative here? It seems like it's getting more immaculate rather than more messy. So you're right that the data came in I would say consistent with but on the high side of expectations. So and if you go back to the former SEP, the last SEP in March you will see that growth moved up. These are not huge moves but growth estimates moved up a bit unemployment estimates moved down a bit. Inflation estimates moved up to bit and you know the all three of those kind of point in the same direction which is you know that perhaps more restraint will be necessary than we had thought at the last meeting. So although the level frankly is pretty the level of 5.6 is pretty consistent if you think about it where the federal funds rate was trading before the bank incidents of early March. So but so we've kind of gone back to that. So your question is where is the disinflation going to come from? And you know I don't think the story has really changed. We the committee has consistently said and believed that the process of getting inflation down is going to be a gradual one. It's going to take some time. And I think you go back to the to the three-part framework for core PC inflation which is we think as good an indicator as you can have for where inflation is going forward. You start with goods with goods we need to see continued healing and supply conditions, supply side conditions. They've definitely improved a substantial amount but if you talk to people in business they will say it's not back to where it was. So that's that's one thing and that should enable goods prices to continue because inflation to continue to come down over time. In terms of housing services inflation that's another big piece and you are seeing there that new rents new leases are coming in at low levels and it's really a matter of time as that goes through the pipeline. In fact I think any forecast that people are making right now about inflation coming down this year will contain a big dose of this year and next year will contain a good amount of disinflation from that source and that's again probably going to come slower than we would affect. That leaves you know the big sector which is a little more than half part of the core PC inflation that's not housing services and you know we see only the earliest signs of disinflation there. It's a sector it's a very broad and diverse sector I would say in a number of the parts of that sector the largest cost would be wage costs. It's a service sector so it's heavily labor intensive and I think many analysts would say that the key to getting inflation down there is to have a continuing loosening in labor market conditions which we have seen. We have actually seen you know go through a number of indicators suggesting there's been some loosening in labor market conditions we need to see that continue. I would almost say that the conditions that we need to see in place to get inflation down are

The expectation is for the Fed to keep rates steady but signal a hike at the July meeting..The widespread bet is that it will resume raising rates in July..That would be the first monthly meeting in more than a year without a rate hike, though the expectation is for the Fed to resume raising rates in July even if it holds steady this week..Yet top Fed officials have made clear that any such pause may be brief — more of a “skip” — with another rate hike likely as soon as their next meeting in late July..The 18 committee members appear split between those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is for at least a few months and see whether inflation further moderates..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 After inflation cooled, investors are expecting a pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hiking campaign that has pushed interest rates to the highest level since 2007..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 The Federal Reserve’s likely decision Wednesday afternoon to leave interest rates alone for the first time in 11 meetings will raise hopes that it may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking campaign to cool inflation..(AP Photo/David Zalubowski)
 NEW YORK – The Federal Reserve's likely decision Wednesday afternoon to leave interest rates alone for the first time in 11 meetings will raise hopes that it may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking campaign to cool inflation..For the Fed to leave rates alone, at least for now, "gives them a little bit of time to evaluate the broader economic and inflationary landscape to see if further rate hikes are warranted.”
 ___
 AP Auto Writer Tom Krisher in Detroit contributed to this report..Market pricing suggests a pause is all but certain, but traders are also bracing for the possibility of a hawkish surprise, with a 60% probability of a 25 basis-point hike priced in by July..Now there’s a growing consensus on Wall Street that central bank officials could restart the hikes, meant to fight elevated inflation, as soon as July..During the Fed policy meeting in May, participants expressed worry that even though the pace of wage growth has been gradually slowing, it’s still “running at a pace that, given current estimates of trend productivity growth, was well above what would be consistent over the longer run with the Committee’s 2% inflation objective,” according to minutes from the meeting..Federal Reserve policy-makers at the end of their two-day meeting may well signal more rate increases are still to come once they take time to assess how the economy is evolving
 Open this photo in gallery: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade, in Washington, on July 31, 2013.Jonathan Ernst/Reuters
 The Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on Wednesday for the first time since the U.S. central bank kicked off a historically aggressive round of monetary policy tightening in March of 2022..Policy-makers at the end of their two-day meeting may well signal more rate increases are still to come once they take time to assess how the economy is evolving, whether the financial system remains stable, and if inflation is continuing to fall..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a “hawkish skip.”
 While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00 per cent-5.25 per cent range, Fed policy-makers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..The expected policy outcome reflects a compromise born of some uncertainty around what it all means, with those Fed officials worried the economy may weaken fast getting at least a six-week timeout until the July 25-26 meeting, and those concerned about still-high inflation readings knowing the central bank will remain primed to move rates higher if price pressures do not relent..The Fed’s last set of quarterly projections anticipated the benchmark overnight interest rate would only move down by the end of 2024 as inflation also declined – movements that keep the inflation-adjusted rate of interest roughly the same..Market participants expect the U.S. central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to pause interest rate hikes because of uncertainty over the economic outlook and the lagged effects of 10 rate increases since March 2022..“Rates will most likely remain unchanged today when the Fed contemplates its next move, but the more salient question is whether this pause also means that the peak rate of the current cycle has been reached or not,” said PVM Oil analyst Tamas Varga..Markets are pricing in a high probability that central bank policymakers will "skip" — an expression they generally prefer to "pause" — at this month's meeting as they digest the impact of 5 percentage points worth of increases going back to March 2022. related investing news Easing inflation pressures give the Fed room to skip a rate hike..watch now
 However, the post-meeting statement could be massaged in a way that markets don't assume that policymakers have gone quiescent on inflation and are set on halting the rate-hiking cycle..The Powell presser
 
 
 Top Fed officials have made clear that any such pause may be brief — more of a “skip” — with another rate hike likely as soon as their next meeting in late July..Washington, DC CNN —
 The Federal Reserve said Wednesday it would pause its historic rate-hiking campaign as it waits for the effects to trickle further through the economy, but signaled that additional rate hikes are likely this year..The Fed’s post-meeting statement confirmed that officials deem the pause a prudent move, but most officials think additional hikes are necessary this year, according to the Fed’s latest Summary of Economic Projections..“Looking ahead, nearly all Committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down 2% over time,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting news conference..“The Fed had to do something to knock market optimism today, otherwise it risks a tougher inflation fight and deeper economic woes down the line.”
 Although the Fed thinks additional policy action is necessary to successfully tamp down inflation, Powell said he’s optimistic about inflation cooling further because of slowing shelter costs, which make up more than 40% of the Consumer Price Index’s core measure..Olivia Cross at Capital Economics in London told UPI that if hiring shows some level of resilience over the coming weeks, it's possible the Fed will hike rates by 25 basis points in July, though she's expecting a pause this week..But at this meeting, considering how far and how fast we have moved, we judged it prudent to hold the target range steady to allow the committee to assess additional information and its implications for monetary policy."."The “data” would certainly appear to be showing easing inflation that would justify the market’s expectations of a pivot in policy – and certainly a pause," says Suderman..New data is supporting the case for a pause in interest rate hikes..Policymakers at the end of their two-day meeting may well signal more rate increases are still to come once they take time to assess how the economy is evolving, whether the financial system remains stable, and if inflation is continuing to fall..While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00%-5.25% range, Fed policymakers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..POLICY COMPROMISE
 Data since the last Fed meeting in early May has left policymakers with a tough set of signals to read, and ample room for debate..“Despite markets pricing very little chance of a rate hike by the Fed tomorrow, we maintain our base case for a 25-basis-point hike,” they said.."The soft inflation report effectively cements a Fed pause, although I doubt it will be enough to warrant a dovish undertone as it's not in their interest with CPI twice the Fed's target," said Matt Simpson, senior market analyst at City Index, who points to 103 as a key support level for the dollar index.

 Recent indicators suggest that economic activity has continued to expand at a modest
 pace..Job gains have been robust in recent months, and the unemployment rate has remained
 low..Inflation remains elevated..Tighter credit conditions for households
 and businesses are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation..In support of these goals, the Committee decided to maintain the
 target range for the federal funds rate at 5 to 5-14 percent..Holding the target range steady at
 this meeting allows the Committee to assess additional information and its implications for
 monetary policy..In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate
 to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative
 tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and
 inflation, and economic and financial developments..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..The Committee
 (more)
 -2-
 would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that
 could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals..The Committee’s assessments will take
 into account a wide range of information, including readings on labor market conditions,
 inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and financial and international developments..Voting for the monetary policy action were Jerome H. Powell, Chair; John C. Williams,
 Vice Chair; Michael S. Barr; Michelle W. Bowman; Lisa D. Cook; Austan D. Goolsbee; Patrick
 Harker; Philip N. Jefferson; Neel Kashkari; Lorie K. Logan; and Christopher J. Waller..For release at 200 p.m. EDT June 14, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on June 14, 2023
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to maintain the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances at 5.15 percent, effective June 15, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to direct the Open
 Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed otherwise, to
 execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with the following
 domestic policy directive
 Effective June 15, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 5 to 5-14 percent..• In a related action, the Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted
 unanimously to approve the establishment of the primary credit rate at the existing level of
 5.25 percent..(more)

 This information will be updated as appropriate to reflect decisions of the Federal Open Market
 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools
 and approach used to implement monetary policy.

similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: basis point hikes, policy firming, labor market conditions, disinflation
2. Second Text: economic activity, job gains, tighter credit conditions, federal funds rate target range

Similarities:

1. Both texts address monetary policy decisions and the Federal Reserve's strategy to manage inflation.
2. Each text acknowledges the importance of economic indicators, such as GDP growth and employment rates, in shaping monetary policy.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes the gradual nature of rate hikes and disinflation, suggesting a cautious approach, while the second text focuses more on job gains and robust economic activity as positive indicators.
2. The first text reflects a more nuanced and detailed perspective on potential future actions regarding inflation, whereas the second text is more straightforward and presents a clear decision regarding the current federal funds rate range.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides an in-depth discussion on the complexities of inflation and labor market dynamics, while the second text summarizes recent economic conditions without detailed explanations.
2. The first text specifically discusses the pace and strategy of interest rate changes in detail over time, while the second text succinctly states the decision to maintain current interest rates.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text frequently uses terms like "initial debate," "live meeting," and "immaculate disinflation," which are not present in the second text.
2. The second text employs phrases such as "cumulative tightening," "inflation expectations," and "primary credit rate," which are not mentioned in the first text.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more negative
Explanation: The first text carries a more negative emotional bias compared to the second text, which is more neutral. In the first text, phrases such as "I want to stress one more thing" and "there was no kind of initial debate about the possibility" reflect a more cautious tone. The use of terms like "slowly progress on inflation" and "it's going to take some time" conveys a sense of uncertainty and concern regarding economic recovery. The second text, on the other hand, includes phrases like "economic activity has continued to expand at a modest pace" and "job gains have been robust," which evoke a more positive outlook on the current economic situation. The overall tone of the second text is more measured and neutral, focusing on stability rather than uncertainty.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: lower certainty 
Explanation: The first text demonstrates a lower level of certainty relative to the second text. The speaker repeatedly emphasizes uncertainty regarding future decisions, as indicated by phrases such as "we didn't make any decision about going forward," and "I would say about July two things. One decision hasn't been made." This language suggests hesitance and a lack of definite conclusions. In contrast, the second text presents a more assertive tone with phrases like "the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening of monetary policy" and "the Committee would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy," indicating a higher level of confidence in proactively managing the economic outlook. The first text's frequent qualifiers and expressions of uncertainty contrast with the assertive and definitive statements found in the second text.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: basis point hikes, disinflation, supply conditions, core PC inflation
2. Second Text: hike at the July meeting, hawkish skip, inflation objectives, economic landscape

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the decision-making processes of the Federal Reserve regarding interest rate hikes.
2. Both texts emphasize the importance of inflation monitoring and its implications for future monetary policy.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses on the nuances of the rate hike decisions and the committee's internal deliberations, while the second text emphasizes market expectations and potential future rate hikes.
2. The first text has a technical tone focused on economic data analysis, whereas the second text conveys a sense of market sentiment and speculation about policy movement.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides detailed analysis on inflation projections and labor market conditions, while the second text is more concise and centered around upcoming decisions and market expectations.
2. The first text discusses the rationale behind the gradual approach and the specific conditions needed for inflation to return to target, while the second text contextualizes this within overall market reactions and expectations for future rate hikes.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text utilizes phrases like "policy firming" and "initial debate," which indicate a more internal and analytical perspective, while the second text uses terms like "hawkish surprise" and "skip," reflecting market behavior and investor sentiment.
2. The first text references specific data points (e.g., unemployment estimates, inflation estimates) that guide policy decisions, whereas the second text focuses more on the consensus and collective expectations of Fed officials and market participants.
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: similarly neutral
Explanation: Both texts maintain a primarily neutral tone, showcasing an objective analysis of the Federal Reserve's monetary policy decisions. In the first text, phrases like "it may make sense for rates to move higher but at a more moderate pace" and "we are really focused on what to do at this meeting" reflect a balanced perspective, showing neither overt optimism nor pessimism. Similarly, the second text states that "the Fed’s last set of quarterly projections anticipated...inflation also declined" and describes the situation as a "hawkish skip," which suggests caution without veering into excessively positive or negative bias. Overall, neither text expresses a strong emotional tilt, opting instead for analytical commentary.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text exhibits a higher level of certainty compared to the second text. For instance, it states, "the committee has consistently said and believed that the process of getting inflation down is going to be a gradual one," indicating a strong confidence in the committee's understanding of inflation trends. In contrast, the second text contains phrases like "the expectation is for the Fed to keep rates steady" and "there’s a growing consensus on Wall Street," conveying a moderate level of certainty but acknowledging some uncertainties about future actions. The fluctuation between certainty and speculation is more pronounced in the second text, reflecting a more cautious approach regarding the Fed's potential decisions.

speech: you know, getting the policy right. And that's what we're doing here. And that's what we'll do for the upcoming meetings. I will say that July meeting will be live. And we'll just have to see. I think you'll see the data. You'll hear fed people talking about it and markets will have to make a judgment. Well, do you think inflation is likely to continue coming down based on the lags and based on your threat of additional movement? Or are we going to be in a period where we're not going to know what's happening? I think if you look at, if you just look at, I'll just point you to the forecast. So inflation is running. Core PCU's inflation is running at about 4 1,5, a little higher than 4 1,5%. And the median FOMC participant thinks it'll go down to 3.9 on a 12-month basis. This is by the end of this year. So that's expecting pretty substantial progress. That's a pretty significant decline for half a year. So that's the forecast. We do try to be transparent in our reaction function. We're committed to getting inflation down. And that's the number one thing. So that's how I think about it. It's going to Victoria. Victoria Guido with Politico. Could you talk about the balance sheet and how you're thinking about it? What are you looking for to judge whether we're approaching reserve scarcity and is treasury issue and going to affect that also are you considering lowering the RRP rate in order to take some pressure off banks? So let me say first of all, on the treasury part of it, if I can talk about that, and then go back to the balance sheet. So on that, of course, we've been very focused on that for a couple of months. As everyone has, treasury has laid out its borrowing plans publicly. I think we all saw. I saw the Secretary's comments yesterday to the effect that treasury has consulted widely with market participants about how to avoid market disruption and that they're going to watch carefully for that. So that's from the treasury, which actually sets the borrowings. At the Fed, we'll be monitoring market conditions carefully as the treasury refills the TGA. The adjustment process is very likely to involve both the reduction in the RRP facility and also in reserves. It's really hard to say at the beginning of this, which will be greater. We are starting at a very high level of reserves and still elevated RRP to take up for that matter. So we don't think reserves are likely to become scarce in the near term, or even over the course of the year. So that's the treasury part of the answer. We will, of course, continue to monitor conditions in money markets, and we're prepared to make adjustments to make sure that monetary policy transmission works. Was there another part of your question? Yeah. Are you considering lowering the RRP rate to help take some pressure off banks? So we have a number of, I would say, the RRP doesn't look like it's pulling money out of the banking system. It's actually been shrinking here lately. So I don't think that's not something we've thought about a lot over time. It doesn't really look like that's something that we would do. I think it's a tool that we have. If we want to use it, we can. There are other tools we can use to address money market issues. But I wouldn't say that that's something that's likely that we would do in the near term. I'll go. Janelle Marte with Bloomberg. Have you seen sufficient cooling in the housing market to bring inflation down? For example, how does the recent rebound affect your forecast? And how does it factor into monetary policy? So certainly housing, very interest-sensitive. And it's the first place, really, or one of the first places that's either helped by lower rates or that is held back by higher rates. And we certainly saw that over the course of the last year. We now see housing putting in a bottom and maybe even moving up a little bit. We're watching that situation carefully. I do think we will see rents and house prices filtering into housing services inflation. And I don't see them coming up quickly. I do see them kind of wandering around at a relatively low level now. And that's appropriate. Do you think you'll have to target with further rate increases? Well, I think we look at everything. We don't just look at housing. So I think the way it works is individual participants sit in their offices all over the country and they write down their forecast. And including their most likely forecast, including their rate forecast. And then they send it in on Friday afternoon. And we accumulate it.

 The Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on Wednesday for the first time since the U.S. central bank kicked off a historically aggressive round of monetary policy tightening in March of 2022..“We probably need a little more tightening, but it is not clear how much,” said Blerina Uruci, chief U.S. economist in the fixed income division at T. Rowe Price Associates, noting that despite strength in recent employment and core inflation reports, a “nuanced” reading of the data showed both may be set to weaken..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a “hawkish skip.”
 While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00 per cent-5.25 per cent range, Fed policy-makers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..The expected policy outcome reflects a compromise born of some uncertainty around what it all means, with those Fed officials worried the economy may weaken fast getting at least a six-week timeout until the July 25-26 meeting, and those concerned about still-high inflation readings knowing the central bank will remain primed to move rates higher if price pressures do not relent..The Fed’s last set of quarterly projections anticipated the benchmark overnight interest rate would only move down by the end of 2024 as inflation also declined – movements that keep the inflation-adjusted rate of interest roughly the same..Market participants expect the U.S. central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to pause interest rate hikes because of uncertainty over the economic outlook and the lagged effects of 10 rate increases since March 2022..watch now
 However, the post-meeting statement could be massaged in a way that markets don't assume that policymakers have gone quiescent on inflation and are set on halting the rate-hiking cycle..The Fed’s post-meeting statement confirmed that officials deem the pause a prudent move, but most officials think additional hikes are necessary this year, according to the Fed’s latest Summary of Economic Projections..“Looking ahead, nearly all Committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down 2% over time,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting news conference..“The Fed is putting more weight on the strong jobs data and sticky core inflation than the slowing headline inflation numbers and is clearly trying to avoid a 1970s style resurgence in inflation,” wrote Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management, in an analyst note..“The Fed had to do something to knock market optimism today, otherwise it risks a tougher inflation fight and deeper economic woes down the line.”
 Although the Fed thinks additional policy action is necessary to successfully tamp down inflation, Powell said he’s optimistic about inflation cooling further because of slowing shelter costs, which make up more than 40% of the Consumer Price Index’s core measure..“I think any forecast that people are making right now about inflation coming down this year will contain a big dose — this year or next year — will contain a good amount of disinflation from that source.”
 Tighter access to credit
 Officials are also keeping a close watch on how credit conditions shape up, considering some lingering stress in the regional banking sector..“We expect Powell will follow up with a relatively hawkish tone in the press conference in order to prevent a dovish market reaction, stressing that inflation is still too high and the Fed will be resolute in returning inflation to target.”
 Wall Street’s “fear gauge” — the Cboe Volatility Index — dropped back below 15, against an average of 23 for the past year, underscoring support for risk assets..The Fed is presented with a careful balancing act with rate hikes, trying to both cool the economy and avoid a recession that would see widespread layoffs..It’s attempting the excruciating balancing act of slowing the economy just enough through rate increases to snuff out high inflation, but not so much as to break the job market and create a recession..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a "hawkish skip."."The soft inflation report effectively cements a Fed pause, although I doubt it will be enough to warrant a dovish undertone as it's not in their interest with CPI twice the Fed's target," said Matt Simpson, senior market analyst at City Index, who points to 103 as a key support level for the dollar index.
extracted_statement_text_10:
Inflation remains elevated..Holding the target range steady at
 this meeting allows the Committee to assess additional information and its implications for
 monetary policy..In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate
 to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative
 tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and
 inflation, and economic and financial developments..In addition, the Committee will continue
 reducing its holdings of Treasury securities and agency debt and agency mortgage-backed
 securities, as described in its previously announced plans..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..The Committee
 (more)
 -2-
 would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that
 could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals..Voting for the monetary policy action were Jerome H. Powell, Chair; John C. Williams,
 Vice Chair; Michael S. Barr; Michelle W. Bowman; Lisa D. Cook; Austan D. Goolsbee; Patrick
 Harker; Philip N. Jefferson; Neel Kashkari; Lorie K. Logan; and Christopher J. Waller..For release at 200 p.m. EDT June 14, 2023
 Decisions Regarding Monetary Policy Implementation
 The Federal Reserve has made the following decisions to implement the monetary policy stance
 announced by the Federal Open Market Committee in its statement on June 14, 2023
 • The Board of Governors of the Federal Reserve System voted unanimously to maintain the
 interest rate paid on reserve balances at 5.15 percent, effective June 15, 2023..• As part of its policy decision, the Federal Open Market Committee voted to direct the Open
 Market Desk at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, until instructed otherwise, to
 execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with the following
 domestic policy directive
 Effective June 15, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate
 in a target range of 5 to 5-14 percent..(more)
 -2-
 This information will be updated as appropriate to reflect decisions of the Federal Open Market
 Committee or the Board of Governors regarding details of the Federal Reserve's operational tools
 and approach used to implement monetary policy.
extracted_news_30:
The expectation is for the Fed to keep rates steady but signal a hike at the July meeting..That's when the Federal Reserve will announce its latest move on interest rates after jacking them to their highest levels since 2007 in hopes of getting high inflation under control..The 18 committee members appear split between those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is for at least a few months and see whether inflation further moderates..At the same time, the gradual but steady decline in overall inflation suggests that the Fed’s rate hikes have had some success..The Fed’s goal is to achieve the delicate task of slowing borrowing and spending enough to cool growth and tame inflation, without derailing the economy in the process..Some economists have suggested that if those measures start to fall and reduce core inflation, the Fed might end up keeping its key rate unchanged for the rest of the year..On Wednesday, Fed officials will also update their quarterly economic projections, including a forecast of what their key rate will be at year’s end..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 After inflation cooled, investors are expecting a pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hiking campaign that has pushed interest rates to the highest level since 2007..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 The Federal Reserve’s likely decision Wednesday afternoon to leave interest rates alone for the first time in 11 meetings will raise hopes that it may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking campaign to cool inflation..IS THE FED MANAGING TO DEFEAT INFLATION?.For the Fed to leave rates alone, at least for now, "gives them a little bit of time to evaluate the broader economic and inflationary landscape to see if further rate hikes are warranted.”

 and businesses are likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation..In support of these goals, the Committee decided to maintain the
 target range for the federal funds rate at 5 to 5-14 percent..Holding the target range steady at
 this meeting allows the Committee to assess additional information and its implications for
 monetary policy..In determining the extent of additional policy firming that may be appropriate
 to return inflation to 2 percent over time, the Committee will take into account the cumulative
 tightening of monetary policy, the lags with which monetary policy affects economic activity and
 inflation, and economic and financial developments..In addition, the Committee will continue
 reducing its holdings of Treasury securities and agency debt and agency mortgage-backed
 securities, as described in its previously announced plans..In assessing the appropriate stance of monetary policy, the Committee will continue to
 monitor the implications of incoming information for the economic outlook..The Committee
 (more)

 would be prepared to adjust the stance of monetary policy as appropriate if risks emerge that
 could impede the attainment of the Committee’s goals..The Committee’s assessments will take
 into account a wide range of information, including readings on labor market conditions,
 inflation pressures and inflation expectations, and financial and international developments..Voting for the monetary policy action were Jerome H. Powell, Chair; John C. Williams,
 Vice Chair; Michael S. Barr; Michelle W. Bowman; Lisa D. Cook; Austan D. Goolsbee; Patrick
 Harker; Philip N. Jefferson; Neel Kashkari; Lorie K. Logan; and Christopher J. Waller..For release at 200 p.m. EDT June 14, 2023

 execute transactions in the System Open Market Account in accordance with the following

 Effective June 15, 2023, the Federal Open Market Committee directs the Desk to
 o Undertake open market operations as necessary to maintain the federal funds rate

similarities_and_differences_with_statem:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: forecast, Core PCU's inflation, balance sheet, reserve scarcity, RRP (Reverse Repo Program), money market conditions, housing services inflation
2. Second Text: elevated inflation, target range for federal funds rate, monetary policy firming, cumulative tightening of monetary policy, labor market conditions, Open Market Desk, agency mortgage-backed securities 

Similarities:

1. Both texts address inflation and its impact on monetary policy.
2. Both texts reference the Federal Reserve's approach to interest rates and the broader economic outlook.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text focuses more on specific economic indicators and forecasts, while the second text emphasizes the broader outcomes of the policy decisions and the reasoning behind maintaining specific interest targets.
2. The first text converses about potential adjustments to policies based on market conditions and individual forecasts, whereas the second text highlights a more formal and procedural announcement of policy decisions.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text includes specific references to inflation rates (e.g., "Core PCU's inflation at about 4.1-5%") providing a detailed analysis, while the second text discusses general targets for federal funds without diving into specific forecasts.
2. The first text discusses various tools available to the Fed (e.g., RRP rate adjustments), while the second focuses on the implementation aspect and operational directives of the Fed's monetary policy.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "balance sheet" and "reserve scarcity," which are not present in the second text.
2. The second text introduces terms such as "target range for federal funds rate" and "monetary policy firming," which are not specifically mentioned in the first text.
sentiment_comparison_with_statement:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text has a subtle positive bias, as seen in phrases such as "we're committed to getting inflation down" and "that's expecting pretty substantial progress." These comments indicate optimism regarding the progress toward lowering inflation. In contrast, the second text expresses a more cautious tone, primarily highlighting challenges with phrases like "inflation remains elevated" and the acknowledgment of "tighter credit conditions... likely to weigh on economic activity, hiring, and inflation." The first text indicates a sense of proactive engagement and potential improvement, whereas the second text conveys a more detached acknowledgment of ongoing issues.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: higher certainty
Explanation: The first text demonstrates a higher level of certainty with phrases such as "I think you'll see the data" and "we do try to be transparent in our reaction function." This shows a commitment to transparency and confidence in forecasting outcomes. The first speaker expresses more definitive statements, showcasing confidence in their assertions. In comparison, the second text contains phrases like "the Committee will take into account the cumulative tightening" and "would be prepared to adjust," which signal a moderate level of certainty and an openness to change in response to new information. This reflects a more cautious approach, thereby positioning it at a lower certainty level than the first text.
similarities_and_differences_with_news:
Unique Key Terms/Phrases:

1. First Text: core PCE, FOMC participant, reserve scarcity, RRP rate, housing services inflation
2. Second Text: hawkish skip, borrowing costs, inflation target, pause in rate hikes, market disruption

Similarities:

1. Both texts discuss the Federal Reserve's monetary policy and decision-making regarding interest rates.
2. Both mention inflation as a central concern guiding the Fed’s policy actions.

Differences:

Themes/Topics with Different Emphasis or Tone:
1. The first text emphasizes the granular details of monetary policy, such as the balance sheet management and the reaction function of the Fed, while the second text focuses more on market predictions and investor expectations.
2. The first text discusses inflation and economic conditions in technical terms, while the second text portrays a broader narrative of Wall Street’s sentiments and the implications of Fed decisions.

Variations in Detail/Scope:
1. The first text provides in-depth commentary on specific metrics like core PCE and housing trends, whereas the second text takes a broader view concerning the Fed's overall strategy and market reactions.
2. The second text mentions specific expectations for a "pause" in rate hikes and addresses public sentiment, while the first text offers more detailed insights regarding internal forecasts and discussions among Fed participants.

Specific Terminology Differences:
1. The first text uses terms like "transparency in reaction function" and "monitoring market conditions," while the second text includes terms like "hawkish skip" and "borrowing costs."
2. The first text discusses "reserve scarcity" and "RRP facility," whereas the second text references "high inflation," "market disruption," and "inflation target."
sentiment_comparison_with_news:
Emotional Bias Comparison:

First text vs Second text: slightly more positive
Explanation: The first text conveys a sense of optimism regarding the Federal Reserve's efforts to tackle inflation and the upcoming meetings. Phrases such as "we're committed to getting inflation down" and "that's expecting pretty substantial progress" illustrate a positive outlook on the Fed's monetary policy efforts. In contrast, the second text uses terms like "uncertainty" and "caution about the economy," suggesting a less optimistic perspective on the Fed's situation, despite acknowledging that rate hikes have had some success. The emphasis on potential further rate increases and fears of a recession in the second text adds a slightly more negative undertone to its analysis.

Certainty Level Comparison:

First text vs Second text: similar certainty
Explanation: Both texts express a moderate level of certainty about the Fed's actions and decisions. The first text states, "we will, of course, continue to monitor conditions in money markets," demonstrating a level of confidence but also openness to changes based on economic indicators. The second text mentions "the expected policy outcome reflects a compromise born of some uncertainty," indicating that there are known dynamics at play but with a mixed outlook. Thus, while both texts acknowledge the complexities and potential uncertainties in the Fed's outlook, they maintain a level of certainty regarding the Fed's direction and strategies, making their certainty levels similar.

speech: and then we publish it for you. So that's how they do that. Well, I don't know that housing is itself going to be driving the rates picture, but it's part of it. Good afternoon. Thank you for taking the question, Mr. Chairman. Edward Lawrence with Fox Business. So I want to go back to comments you made about in the past, about unsustainable fiscal path. The CBO projects the federal deficit to be 2.8 trillion in 10 years. The CBO also says that federal debt will be 52 trillion by 2033. At what point do you talk more firmly with lawmakers about fiscal responsibility? Because I'm assuming monetary policy cannot handle alone the inflation or keep that inflation in check with the higher level spending? I don't do that. That's really not my job. We hope and expect that other policymakers will respect our independence on monetary policy. And we don't see ourselves as the judges of appropriate fiscal policy. I will say, and many of my predecessors have said that we are on an unsustainable fiscal path, and that needs to be addressed over time. But I think trying to get into that with lawmakers would be inappropriate given our independence and our need to stick to our netting. Is there any conversation then about the federal's financing some of that debt that we're seeing come not the pike? No. Under no circumstances. Courtney. Thanks for taking our questions, Chair Powell. So looking at the SEP, it looks like GDP for this year was raised significantly, or forecast for GDP this year. The unemployment rate, meanwhile, was pulled downward. And so should we take that as a sign that the committee is more confident about the prospects of a soft landing, at least as it relates to what you're expecting in March? You know, I would just say it this way. I continue to think, and this really hasn't changed, that there is a path to getting inflation back down to 2% without having to see the kind of sharp downturn and large losses of employment that we've seen in so many past instances. It's possible in a way a strong labor market is that gradually cools, could aid that along. It could aid that along. But I guess I want to come back to the main thing, which is, though, simply this, we see the committee, as you can see from the SEP, the committee is completely unified in the need to get inflation down to 2%. And we'll do whatever it takes to get it down to 2% over time. That is our plan. And we understand that allowing inflation to get entrenched into the US economy is the thing that we cannot allow to happen for the benefit of today's workers and families and businesses, but also for the future. Getting price stability back and restored will benefit generations of people as long as it's sustained. And it really is the bedrock of the economy. And you should understand that that is our top priority. Just a quick follow-up on that. I'm just a little confused because you said the committee will do whatever it takes to get inflation down over time. But when I look at the SEP, inflation is still projected to be elevated next year. But the Fed funds rate is lower than where it is now. Can you help me understand that? Sure. So if you look two and three years out with the forecast, first of all, I wouldn't put too much weight on forecasts even one year out because they're so highly uncertain. But what they're showing is that as inflation comes down in the forecast, if you don't lower interest rates, then real rates are actually going up. So just to maintain a real rate, the nominal rate at that point two years out, let's say, should come down just to maintain real rates. And actually, since we're probably going to have to be meaningfully positive and significantly, so for us to get inflation down, that probably means that that certainly means that it will be appropriate to cut rates at such time as inflation is coming down really significantly. And again, we're talking about a couple years out. I think as anyone can see, not a single person on the committee wrote down a rate cut this year. Nor do I think it is all likely to be appropriate. If you think about it, inflation has not really moved down. It is not so far reacted much to our existing rate hikes. And so we're going to have to keep that. Julie. I'm Rachel for our Jewish Abedist, anything? I'm Michael Scott. I'm sorry.

 Thats when the Federal Reserve will announce its latest move on interest rates after jacking them to their highest levels since 2007 in hopes of getting high inflation under control.The wide expectation on Wall Street is that the Fed will make no move, which would be the first time in more than a year where it hasnt raised rates..That's when the Federal Reserve will announce its latest move on interest rates after jacking them to their highest levels since 2007 in hopes of getting high inflation under control..She said that while easing inflation data "reduces the risk that the Fed may have to keep hiking into the 6% range, the data is not enough to conclude that the Fed will ease anytime soon.".Fed Chair Jerome Powell and other top policymakers have also indicated that they want to assess how much a pullback in bank lending might be weakening the economy..The 18 committee members appear split between those who favor one or two more rate hikes and those who would like to leave the Fed’s key rate where it is for at least a few months and see whether inflation further moderates..On Wednesday, Fed officials will also update their quarterly economic projections, including a forecast of what their key rate will be at year’s end..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 After inflation cooled, investors are expecting a pause in the Federal Reserve's rate hiking campaign that has pushed interest rates to the highest level since 2007..“Overall, the inflation data support a hold in policy at today’s (Fed) meeting.’’
 
 
 The Federal Reserve’s likely decision Wednesday afternoon to leave interest rates alone for the first time in 11 meetings will raise hopes that it may be nearing the end of its rate-hiking campaign to cool inflation..“That might mean the Fed is going to have to hold rates higher for longer, and it may even mean boosting rates further in the months ahead,” McBride said..“It just means they may be willing to hold rates where they are and let the economy continue to settle without more rate-related prodding in the immediate future.”
 If the economy does cool, Channel predicts that mortgage rates may end the year closer to 6% than to 7%..For the Fed to leave rates alone, at least for now, "gives them a little bit of time to evaluate the broader economic and inflationary landscape to see if further rate hikes are warranted.”
 ___
 AP Auto Writer Tom Krisher in Detroit contributed to this report..During the Fed policy meeting in May, participants expressed worry that even though the pace of wage growth has been gradually slowing, it’s still “running at a pace that, given current estimates of trend productivity growth, was well above what would be consistent over the longer run with the Committee’s 2% inflation objective,” according to minutes from the meeting..Federal Reserve policy-makers at the end of their two-day meeting may well signal more rate increases are still to come once they take time to assess how the economy is evolving
 Open this photo in gallery: An eagle tops the U.S. Federal Reserve building's facade, in Washington, on July 31, 2013.Jonathan Ernst/Reuters
 The Federal Reserve is expected to leave interest rates unchanged on Wednesday for the first time since the U.S. central bank kicked off a historically aggressive round of monetary policy tightening in March of 2022..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a “hawkish skip.”
 While likely to forego an increase in borrowing costs after 10 consecutive hikes that have pushed the benchmark overnight interest rate to the current 5.00 per cent-5.25 per cent range, Fed policy-makers at the same time are expected to show both in their language and projections that one or perhaps two more quarter-percentage-point hikes will still be needed by the end of 2023..The expected policy outcome reflects a compromise born of some uncertainty around what it all means, with those Fed officials worried the economy may weaken fast getting at least a six-week timeout until the July 25-26 meeting, and those concerned about still-high inflation readings knowing the central bank will remain primed to move rates higher if price pressures do not relent..The Fed’s last set of quarterly projections anticipated the benchmark overnight interest rate would only move down by the end of 2024 as inflation also declined – movements that keep the inflation-adjusted rate of interest roughly the same..Market participants expect the U.S. central bank’s Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) to pause interest rate hikes because of uncertainty over the economic outlook and the lagged effects of 10 rate increases since March 2022..Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell holds a news conference after the release of U.S. Fed policy decision on interest rates, in Washington, May 3, 2023..Communication from the Fed, then, likely will be, "We're not convinced that this is the end of the rate hikes, but we want to take a look around see what kind of damage the banking crisis has inflicted on the economy," said Mark Zandi, chief economist at Moody's Analytics..“Looking ahead, nearly all Committee participants view it as likely that some further rate increases will be appropriate this year to bring inflation down 2% over time,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in his post-meeting news conference..“The Fed is putting more weight on the strong jobs data and sticky core inflation than the slowing headline inflation numbers and is clearly trying to avoid a 1970s style resurgence in inflation,” wrote Seema Shah, chief global strategist at Principal Asset Management, in an analyst note..“The Fed had to do something to knock market optimism today, otherwise it risks a tougher inflation fight and deeper economic woes down the line.”
 Although the Fed thinks additional policy action is necessary to successfully tamp down inflation, Powell said he’s optimistic about inflation cooling further because of slowing shelter costs, which make up more than 40% of the Consumer Price Index’s core measure..“I think any forecast that people are making right now about inflation coming down this year will contain a big dose — this year or next year — will contain a good amount of disinflation from that source.”
 Tighter access to credit
 Officials are also keeping a close watch on how credit conditions shape up, considering some lingering stress in the regional banking sector..“The economy is facing headwinds from tighter credit conditions for households and businesses, which are likely to weigh on economic activity and inflation,” Powell said..Economists say the July meeting will be a close call and Powell said in his presser that officials will examine “a three-month period of data” for that decision..“We expect Powell will follow up with a relatively hawkish tone in the press conference in order to prevent a dovish market reaction, stressing that inflation is still too high and the Fed will be resolute in returning inflation to target.”
 Wall Street’s “fear gauge” — the Cboe Volatility Index — dropped back below 15, against an average of 23 for the past year, underscoring support for risk assets..Most Read from Bloomberg Businessweek
 ©2023 Bloomberg L.P.
 
 
 Something of a neutral report on consumer-level inflation in the U.S. economy should give the Federal Reserve reason to pump the brakes on additional rate hikes for now, analysts said Tuesday..1/2
 Federal Reserve Chairman Jerome Powell is expected to make no change to interest rate policies on Wednesday, despite so-called core inflation running higher than expected..The Fed is presented with a careful balancing act with rate hikes, trying to both cool the economy and avoid a recession that would see widespread layoffs..Olivia Cross at Capital Economics in London told UPI that if hiring shows some level of resilience over the coming weeks, it's possible the Fed will hike rates by 25 basis points in July, though she's expecting a pause this week..However, Chair Jerome Powell said in a press conference, "Nearly all committee participants expect that it will be appropriate to raise interest rates somewhat further by the end of the year..The U.S. Federal Reserve is expected to make an announcement today regarding interest rates..A sense of caution about the economy competing with ongoing inflation concerns has led the Fed to this point, on the verge of what analysts are calling a "hawkish skip.".** Indicates new events ------------------------------------------------------------- WEDNESDAY, JUNE 14 WASHINGTON, D.C. - U.S. Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) begins its two-day meeting on interest rates (final day)

 PHILADELPHIA, United States - Federal Reserve Bank of Philadelphia issues Manufacturing Business Outlook Survey for June..TUESDAY, JULY 25 WASHINGTON, D.C. - U.S. Federal Reserve's Federal Open Market Committee (FOMC) starts its two-day meeting on interest rates (to July 26) WEDNESDAY, JULY 26 OTTAWA - The Bank of Canada releases its monetary policy deliberations held before its July 12 rate decision.
